text:
This was awesome.  One modification, as per some earlier readers' comments:  Before doing anything, I browned six strips of bacon in the large skillet, removed them and let them drain.  Then, I added the veggies to the bacon fat and proceeded as described (with clam juice, water, etc.)  Crumbled the bacon into the soup after it was all combined.  Adds fat, but a huge flavor too.  Simply outstanding recipe here -- I love the red wine vinegar idea.  Thank you!!

text:
Very good base recipe but definitely does not warrant five stars. To increase flavor, I substituted clam juice for the water, added bacon grease in leiu of half the butter.  The bacon grease, while not exactly healthy, gave the chowder a better flavor (IMPORTANT NOTE:  You must let the roux cook down before adding the half and half ~ this will eliminate the flour taste that so many are noting in their reviews). Added 1/2 teaspoon of Bay Seasoning and 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder for more flavor.  Used a mix of chopped and minced clams and substituted 1/2 teaspoon garlic salt for a portion of the 1 1/2 teaspoon regular salt.  Stirred only 1 tablespoon of the vinegar into the chowder prior to serving.  Topped the chowder with crumbled bacon and a few chives for color.  Helpful Tips:  For a smokey flavor, add 1/2 teaspoon of liquid smoke which adds depth and complexity to the chowder base.  Add fresh grilled corn cut off the cob which increases the smokey flavor.  Replace black ground pepper with white pepper ~ it has a more delicate flavor than the ground black pepper which can be rather harsh with such a creamy base.  Most Important:  Do not add the clams to the chowder until you are ready to serve ~ the longer seafood "cooks" the tougher it becomes!  Delicious with the changes.

text:
I have been a clam chowder fan for as long as I can remember.  I order clam chowder often - when it's available.  This recipe is exceptional and compares favorably with the best clam chowder recipes I've tasted in fine restaurants.  I did the bacon thing as many other reviewers recommended.  I'm glad I did.  It added just one more interesting taste element to this already fantastic flavored soup.  I prefer my soup thick, so I used all 1/2 & 1/2 as well as a trace of heavy whipping cream that I wanted to get rid of.  When the soup was slightly thicker than even I like, I thinned it out ever so slightly with a little skim milk.  The only recommendation I might add, for those that prefer the consistency of more substantial clam;  get the chopped clam instead of the minced.  I think that's what I'll do next time I fix this, which will be often!  It's good enough to be an award winning soup!

text:
Very good recipe and is now a keeper in my personal recipes.  I left out the celery and carrots due to veggie pickiness in the family and was concerned that would affect the overall flavor.  Not a bit.  Interestingly, I tasted it prior to adding the salt and red wine vinegar.  VERY bland, uninteresting.  I added the salt, OK, that picked it up so that it started to taste like clam chowder.  But the real kick was the vinegar.  It brought it all together with a great taste!  BTW, as suggested by others I used all clam juice instead of water, added some bacon and sauted the onion in the bacon fat before adding the potatoes and clam juice.  Minor changes but bacon just sounded so good.  Well done, Sharon!

text:
Delicious!!  I make this recipe twice a month. Following other reviews, I use cornstarch instead of flour. I heat the cream (fat free) over low heat, while the vegetables are simmering. I mix 3/4 cornstarch in with 1/4 cup milk, then add that to the cream. I don't use the red wine vinegar, b/c I don't think it needs it. I also add Old Bay seasoning, garlic and onion powder, and I use dried minced onion instead of fresh. LOVE THIS RECIPE!!

text:
We lapped this stuff up!  I was dubious first because there was a lot of vegetables and juice in the first mixture, but it all mixed together wonderfully! 

I also used part half&half and part skim milk and it was still VERY rich.  I also added some chopped fresh parsley at the very end and will try it with some bacon next time, although honestly it does'nt need it.

I also recommend using bottled clam juice in place of the water if you like more of a sea taste for your chowder and I used 3 cans of chopped clams and 2 cans of minced.  It makes a LOT of leftovers and I froze them for a later meal.

country:

text:
I am a chef and make clam chowder in restaurants and catering and use a similar recipe when I make it.  This recipe seems quite solid but here is what I do if anyone wants to try a little spin on it.  I add some fresh garlic to the sauteed veggies while they cook in bacon fat with a dash of butter(salt pork or ham hocks also work well here)  I do not use any onion at all but substitute shallot instead and nearly carmalize all the veggies first.  I do not use any half and half but instead use an extra can (or make your own) clam juice/stock and make up for the added water content by using heavy cream.   You wont need quite as much heavy cream as it calls for half and half and it still comes out nice and creamy with a little more clam flavor.  I add the chopped crispy bacon and clams towards the end of the cooking process as to not have tough clams or rubbery bacon with less flavor.  Try it out if you like...i also cook soup with a couple bay leaves, a little celery salt, thyme and a couple other minor adds that i like in clam chowder.

text:
This is now my best clam chowder. It was fantastic! I made it pretty much as is with only slight changes. I used 4 cans of clams, next time I will use 5 because the hubby loves a lot of clams and use whole BABY clams. I will nix the carrots as it is I just used half a cup but the hubby dislikes like cooked carrots so he wasn't crazy about that and quite frankly I've never had carrots in my chowda. Next time I will try it adding   some bacon as was the other half's suggestion and I didn't even mention the other reviews to him. And I used clam juice instead of water. An 8oz bottle with the juice from 4 cans of clams was enough to cover the veggies. The red wine vinegar in it was outta this world! never in a million years would I have guessed it. What a superb super secret ingredient! This is getting written in my family favorites book tonight! I served it it warm bread bowls, perfect for a cold rainy new england day.  Side note: we like our chowda thick so I cooked it a little longer to where it was thicker than pancake batter before adding the veggies and juice. Perfect! If its to think for you then it can be thinned with a little milk.  ****Update**** I entered this in a Contest and took second with it after my husband said there was no way a flatlander could win in New England with Chowder. It was my first time trying to reheat it in a crock pot, I made the night before and didnt add the clams or red wine vinegar as well as left the potatoes and veggies a little more firm. 3

text:
Good recipe but I made some changes.  On the ingredient list I added 4 slices of diced bacon, increased potatoes to 3 cups, added 3 cloves garlic (diced), added 1 can chicken broth, reduced butter to 1/2 cup and reduced all-purpose flour to 1/4 cup and the next time will reduce red wine vineger down to 1.5 T.  On the directions I sauteed the bacon in a 5 quart dutch oven over medium heat.  When crisp I added the onions, celery and garlic until they started to get translucent.  I later added the carrots and 5 minutes later added the potatoes.  I let them cook for about 5 minutes and then added the clam juice and instead of water added the chicken broth - just enough to barely cover.  I added some salt and pepper and brought to a simmer for about 20 minutes.  In the meantime in a small saucepan I melted the 1/2 cup butter and wisked in the 1/4 cup flour - I then added the half and half until this got thick.  I then poured this over the vegetable, clam juice and chicken broth mixture and later added the clams as informed below and also the vinegar.  My husband absolutely loved this recipe.  Thank you Pioneergirl... (I know I made some changes but you gave an excellent base recipe and I just incorporated some changes from my years of experience in making fish and clam chowders).

text:
Delish.... Ok, I made a few changes but not many. First let me start off by saying that if you like your chowder on the thicker side just cook the half & half mixture a bit longer. Come on people! That is cooking 101. Now that I got that out of the way, I did cook off 6 strips of bacon and then put the veggies in the grease along with the juice from 2 cans of whole baby clams as well as a small jar of clam juice. I did not use water nor the minced clams. I used 2 10oz cans of whole baby clams to really get that full clam taste I like. Also, using the clam juice instead of the water does not make it too clammy at all but instead just right when mixed all together. Other than those 3 changes i cooked the recipe exactly as written. I think next time I will add some corn though as I personally love corn in chowder. This was delish. Thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I peeled and cubed 6 med potatoes, with garlic, diced onion, and frozen corn and boiled this in clam juice and water til tender. I diced leftover Green lipped mussels, shrimp, and slip lobster tails, and added this to the veggies near the end to prevent the seafood from becoming rubbery. I also used 2 cups half-n-half and 2 cups of 2% milk, omited the flour, and used 1/4 cup corn starch instead (no flour taste).  I used another recipe idea (found on this site) and added 8 oz of cream cheese with the milk, stirring til smooth.  And don't forget the red wine vinegar! It brings out the flavor of the seafood!  This chowder was so creamy and just the right thickness with loads of flavor!  It is also great as leftovers the next day, if you have any leftover that is!  10 stars!!!

text:
Perfect when followed Crystal S's suggestions:  "Very good base recipe but definitely does not warrant five stars. To increase flavor, I substituted clam juice for the water, added bacon grease in leiu of half the butter. The bacon grease, while not exactly healthy, gave the chowder a better flavor (IMPORTANT NOTE: You must let the roux cook down before adding the half and half ~ this will eliminate the flour taste that so many are noting in their reviews). Added 1/2 teaspoon of Bay Seasoning and 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder for more flavor. Used a mix of chopped and minced clams and substituted 1/2 teaspoon garlic salt for a portion of the 1 1/2 teaspoon regular salt. Stirred only 1 tablespoon of the vinegar into the chowder prior to serving. Topped the chowder with crumbled bacon and a few chives for color. Helpful Tips: For a smokey flavor, add 1/2 teaspoon of liquid smoke which adds depth and complexity to the chowder base. Add fresh grilled corn cut off the cob which increases the smokey flavor. Replace black ground pepper with white pepper ~ it has a more delicate flavor than the ground black pepper which can be rather harsh with such a creamy base. Most Important: Do not add the clams to the chowder until you are ready to serve ~ the longer seafood "cooks" the tougher it becomes! Delicious with the changes."

I learned how to make clam chowder from my Nova Scotian mother and the first part of the process was to boil some patatoes with extra water, mash them and that became the thickener rather than flour. Now I simply use more patatoes to adjust the desired thickness

text:
I've been looking for an actual "Chowder" recipe NOT "Soup" and I have finally found it.  Some of the other recipes have a lighter soupy consistency, so if that's what you're looking for, then this is not the recipe for you.  My son, who does not like clam chowder, surprisingly had seconds last night.  I have found the perfect recipe for my family and friends.  I did make some modifications, to our taste.  I added a bottle of clam juice, an extra can of clams and 2 cans of canned shrimp.  Note: If you use the full quart of half-and-half, it will come out VERY creamy.  I had to add some milk and some cornstarch to even out the flavor. I left out the red-wine vinegar to be added invidiually by family members as not everyone liked the vinger added.  I also left out the carrots, seeing as they don't really fit into the clam chowder.  Otherwise, this was an excellent thick and creamy chowder, just like our family likes it.

I put both light cream and 2 % Milk which I think gives it the same amount of sweetness that all cream would give which I think has kicked it up a notch with my new addition.

text:
Made tonight with a few changes. Browned 6 pieces of chopped bacon (husband requested), removed bacon, then sautéed celery and onion and a bit of minced garlic in the drippings. Added the juice of 4 cans of clams (again, husband requested extra clamminess) and chopped red potatoes, needed no extra water to cover. Made the roux with 1 stick butter and 3/4 cup flour and 1 qt whole milk. Simmered while whisking until thick and potatoes were cooked through. Combined all in Dutch oven and warmed through. Added a splash of red wine vineagar to our bowls. Served with crusty ciabatta rolls. Ah. Maxing. Silky smooth and creamy and delicious and savory. Will be making again and again.

This clam chowder knocked my socks off!  I did saute my onions in a little bacon grease and added some chopped bacon at the end, but other than that, I stuck to the recipe.  I was curious to see what the vinegar would do to the recipe.  I tasted it before and after adding the vinegar, and all I can say is that it is an integral component. text:
Very mediocre. A lot of the reviews tell a tale of all the things they did to change it - all these things were done to make it good, and the original recipe is really not that good.
It is a tad thick, and has almost no real flavor. It is a mash of floured cream with clam and veggies. I didn't even notice the vinegar doing anything to spruce it up.
All that being said, it is a great base recipe. Add whatever you like, revore what you dont. The bacon is a good add, and clam juice instead of water for a fuller clam flavor. I think a dash of cayenne pepper would kick it up enough to make it tasty.
I will make it again, and modify it heavily, but this recipe is not the 5 stars it has been voted.

text:
This was he first time I tried making clam chowder and it came out great. As others suggested, I fried 4 or 5 slices of bacon until crispy and sauteed the vegetables in the drippings. Other changes I made were using 2 cans of minced clams and 2 cans of chopped; increasing the potatoes to about 4 cups; I used light half-and-half and light butter to try to cut down on the fat and calories, and it still came out creamy and delicious. My fiance is from Massachusetts and she was skeptical of me trying to make "chowdah", but she loved it. I definitely will be making this again.

Great recipe!  I had to change a few things because my cupboards were bare but this recipe is an excellent base for any variation of seafood chowder.  I used 2% milk and mixed it with the flour like a roux, to about a peanut butter color. I also added a can of tuna and a can of salmon because I was short one can of clams and I wanted that fishy taste. I also used homemade chicken broth instead of water to soften the veg.    The results were divine!   Thanks for sharing the recipe.

text:
Minor adjustments and this is AMAZING: I use 5 cans of chopped clams instead of 3 (can you ever have too many?), 1.5 cups chopped onion, 1.5 cups sliced celery, 1.5 cups sliced carrots, and I skip the potatoes.  I also replace the quart of half-and-half with 1 pint half-and-half and 1 pint skim milk.  Made it for Thanksgiving dinner this year, and the entire (HUGE) pot disappeared!  Also perfect for cold days when you need to heat things up a bit, and lasts for a good few meals if you just pair it with some sourdough or french bread.

text:
A little bland and pasty 

The roux should be cooked more, less butter in it and less roux in general. 

I would add whites of leek

Fresh chopped thyme

White pepper instead of black

Lemon juice instead of vinegar

Clam base instead of salt (no mono-sodium glutamate) 

Cook the potatoes separately

Cook the vegetables in descending order,start with the celery(it takes the longest) then add the onion then the carrot and leek, then add the roux,clam juice and half and half.

text:
I've made this soup twice now with the following changes:  sauteed vegetables in 1/4 cup butter; then added clam juice from 2 cans of baby clams.  I then added 3-4 cups of water and let it all simmer until the veggies were tender.  I added the clams and about 1-2 cups of chopped imitation crab - you could use real crab if you desire for an even more authentic taste.  Mixed this with the butter/flour/cream mixture and let it simmer for about 5 minutes.  My husband goes nuts over this - he's from the East Coast (we live on the Canadian prairies) and he admits it's even better than his mom's back in beautiful Cape Breton!  This is perfection!

OMG, this was FABULOUS!!!  I am allergic to dairy (cow) so I used canned, evaporated goat's milk instead of 1/2 & 1/2.  Was velvety smooth and lucious.  Also followed others reco and added some chopped crisp bacon, cooking the veggies in the grease and using bottled clam juice instead of water.  Also, cooked the flour/margerine (non dairy) for a few minutes to remove flour taste.  We had tonight for Christmas eve and my husband and I both gorged saying we will serve to a crowd next time with pride.  Simply outstanding.  Thank you for a magnificant new addition to our festivities.

This chowder is awesome. i ommitted the carrots and made up for them with and extra cup of potatoes. my mother didn't like the red wine vinegar so the last few times i've made this recipe 
I've added a splash of white wine in the pan I started the potatoes in and I add 1/2 a cup of chedder cheese 5 minutes before serving.
Also DON'T ADD SALT the clams and thier juice add salt naturally, and salt is one of those things you leave for a picky guest to dicide on AFTER you put the bowl in front of them.

text:
I started following this recipe in 2005. I have not used another one since. I do not always follow it to the Letter though. I add a 1/2 pound of bacon/ham pieces, tsp of curry and tsp of marjoram. My wife and I do our own clamming and crabbing on the Oregon coast. We will use whatever shellfish we have on hand. Any combination of clams or crab works great in this recipe. This recipe is incredibly easy to make. After a while, you can make it by memory. Not a single person who has tried has complained. Almost everybody goes back for seconds.

text:
This certainly is a splurge on calories and fat even using fat-free half and half, but WOW is it good.  The consistency, in particular, is absolutely perfect...thick and creamy exactly the way clam chowder should be.  I have access to fresh clams, but I honestly don't think that preparation is worth the effort when you get something this good from  canned clams.  One thing I will mention is that it did take some time for the cream to thicken, so I would start that sooner the next time.  I got my veggies cooking and then started the roux, and the veggies were done before the cream thickened.  I could see adding a bacon garnish, but other than that, I wouldn't change a thing.  Thanks Pioneergirl for sharing your recipe.  This one's going into my favorites!

This was delicious. My husband and I are clam chowder coneseurs and we thought this was pretty good. Another thing is to use the chopped clams not minced. Delicious eaten out of a bread bowl.

text:
This is almost an exact copy of the Ivar's Clam Chowder recipe that circulates around Seattle (home of Ivar's Seafood restaurants), but that doesn't mean it's not freakin' awesome!  I love going home to Seattle for a bowl of Ivar's clam chowder, and this recipe is very close to the creamy, thick, tasty goodness you can get at Ivar's.  This is a clam chowder recipe that will convert clam chowder haters (including picky kids) into fans because it is mostly creamy and not very clammy/fishy.  I agree with other reviewers, adding bacon definitely helps.

text:
I have been making this for years and it is soooo good. Sometimes I do cheat and use skim milk/less butter and use more veggies to begin with (wich I add some chicken stock/clam juice), then put about half in a blender and add it back to chowder before finishing. It makes it thicker with out the fat. Not quite as good but close enough to eat on a regular basis for lunch.  Don't be scared of the vinegar it's yummy - if you are cooking for a crowd don't add it and leave the bottle out so everyone can add their own.  Thank you 8 - )

text:
Amazing chowder! However, I changed a few things to make it super good! I used 3 cans of chopped clams and then 2 cans of minced clams (becuase I like a much more "seafood" taste to my chowder), which was barely enough juice to cover the vegetables. I ommitted the carrots, since I do not care for them or feel they belong in clam chowder. I also used 1/2 quart of half-and-half and 1/2 quart of milk so the soup wouldn't be too rich, but just right! I only used 1 tablespoon of the vinegar, since I was a bit leary of it, but next time will definitely try 2 tablespoons, the vinegar was great! I also added parsley to give it a little added flavor, and there was no soup left! Excellent recipe!

country:

text:
I'm a little bit surprised at the reviews on this recipe.  Consistency was good if you like nice and thick chowder, but the taste was a tad bit lacking.  If you have never made chowder before, then I suppose this would be a good recipe.  On the other hand, if your a chowder buff, you may be a bit disappointed.  I didn't add the bacon as others suggested, may be I should have.  Be sure to cook the flour mixture a bit, otherwise you will have a flour taste.  And go easy on the red wine vinegar.  I could taste it once I was done.  I did add more clams and used a combo of chopped and minced.  I like larger clams (not too big) and was glad that I did this.  Not a bad recipe, but certainly not 5 stars in my book.  Sorry I couldn't rate this better, just being honest.

text:
The best clam chowder I've ever had!  I followed others advice and used 3 cans chopped/2 cans minced clams.  The juice from those gave me plenty of liquid to cover the veggies.  I also added some bacon and I used only 1 TBSP of vinegar.  My only suggestion in cooking the veggies, would be to let the carrots/celery go for a little while before adding the potatoes/onions.  They seem to take longer and I didn't want the potatoes to be mush so the carrots were a little crunchy still.  I will make this recipe all the time!  Thanks!

By far the best clam chowder recipe I have followed. text:
This is a very good clam chowder recipe!  It was my first time making the chowder and I used the other reviewer's tips of incorporating bacon into the chowder.  I cooked the bacon first and then tossed the veggies, water, and clam water into the bacon grease, yum! I did notice that I cut the potatoes too small so when they were fully cooked, the celery and carrots were still a little crunchy. Be mindful of the chunk size of the potatoes is my advice, but I am a novice cooker so you guys must already know it!  Also, I used 1 pint of half and half and 1 pint of non fat milk to make the two quarts, I did not want it to be too heavy.  It turned out great! I had two bowls of this soup and it is serious comfort food.  I'm making this soup for my boyfriend when he comes back from Afghanistan.

userID:
10809311
Display Name:
clearady
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674141.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good.  I halved the recipe, because as is, it makes too much for just two people.  I like leftovers for chicken noodle and tomato basil, but prefer none in this.

I left out the onion and carrots because they just aren't necessary to me.


I made some bacon beforehand to crumble into the soup.  Popped it into the over at 400 degrees for 13 minutes.  Pulled it out right before it turned crispy and reserved the bacon fat.  


I simmered the potato in the juice from the canned clams, bacon fat, and also another bottle of clam juice. 

Then I crumbled the bacon into the potatoes at 10 minutes and also add the celery at this time.  IF you put the celery sooner, it just becomes mush.  The potatoes should be on for at least 20 minutes, however, to get that melt-in-your-mouth texture.


The only other changes I made was I cut the red wine vinegar by half (can always add more if necessary) and cut the butter/half half/all purp by a third, as I like my soup not incredibly thick. 


I love it the way I have it!  Delicious with sourdough bread.

text:
Wow, this clam chowder is the best! It's rich, hearty and packed with flavor. The celery, carrots and onions that are simmered in the clam juice adds to the flavor of the vegetables.

This isnt a thin chowder by any means, it is thick, rich and flavorful. There's no need to adjustment this recipe..If you don't care for some of the ingredients, don't spoil it by altering the flavor because it's simply perfect as is.

It takes less than a half hour to make, but tastes like it simmered for hours. If you like a hearty and flavorful clam chowder, try this recipe, you wont be disappointed.

Thank you for this outstanding recipe PIONEERGIRL.

text:
Very nice recipe :). I used clam juice (from the cans) + 2 extra bottles instead of using water, and instead of putting carrots I just added a bit more potato and celery. I also sauteed my veggies in the bacon fat (and cut down the amount of butter). At first I was very skeptical of the red wine vinegar so did not put it into my pot of soup...Instead I put in a few drops into my own bowl. I was quite surprised how well it worked and will definitely add it straight into the soup next time :). 

Lastly for those who are saying that the clam chowder tastes like flour: You need to cook the raw flour taste of our your roux before adding in the 1/2 & 1/2.

Fantastic, and so easy!  I added some chopped up broiled bacon to the soup when I added the cream/roux.  Husband loved it.  I couldn't find clams so I bought a jar of pickled cockles, which I wasn't sure would work but it turned out I didn't have any vinegar in the house so it worked out fine.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious! So simple. I used red potatoes, and added a leek. I also used 3 strips of bacon as per suggested and softened the veggies in the bacon grease before adding the clam juice from the cans. I used 4 cans of clams, 2 minced and 2 chopped, because we like the clam flavor. I used flour instead of cornstarch and added milk since it thickened up quite a bit. Old Bay Seasoning and the red vinegar really made it sing. So good and so filling! Served with an artisan crusty bread and the whole family gobbled it up.

text:
I microwave the veggies in a bowl with a little bit of water in the bottom for 2 min. each bowlful.  Dump everything in the crockpot on high.  Cleanup was easy.  I had to wash my chopping knife, a spoon, and a bowl.....eyeballed the measuring parts.  Done in 1 hour, while I'm watching the football game. Voila!

Fantastic recipe.  I plan to make this again and again. A couple things I would do differently:  a) mince and fry some bacon and add to the celery/carrots and add onions.   b) Instead of using half and half (to avoid some serious fat) use 2 cups 2% milk and the other 2 cups half and half (fat free).

country:
None
text:
*5 stars the way I make it* I add extra potatoes because I like it chunkier, and although I like thick soups, half and half makes it WAY to thick, like sludge. Making it with regular milk thickens up perfectly with the flour. I use white pepper instead of black and I add some onion powder. I also reduce the amount of red wine vinegar. I have made it the other way, it was too thick, didn't have enough stuff in it, almost just pure sauce, and the red wine vinegar was over powering. The changes I make make sure it's gobbled up at my house.

text:
This turned out really well. I cooked in big crockpot so I doubled the recipe and it filled it to the brim. The one thing you shold do if cooking in crock pot is step number two. Do that first and then throw everything into the crockpot and let it cook on low for 6 to 8 hours. For step 2 I melted the butter and combined all the wet ingredients and then added the flour. It left little clumps of flour throughout. In the end it still tasted great but didn't turn out too pretty.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making clam chowder, and as many have before, I loved this recipe!  Although I personally wanted to try the bacon version that was recommended by others, I was making this for someone who doesn't eat pork and is trying to lose weight, therefore I altered the recipe slightly, following the advice of another reviewer:  sweated off the onion in a little olive oil before adding the other veggies, used all clam juice instead of water, reduced butter and flour to 1/2 cup each, and used fat-free half and half.  It was delicious and just the right thickness for our taste.  Great recipe!

0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum.....This chowder is sooooooooo good.  I did make a couple of alterations, using a technique from another recipe on this website.  After 1st chopping and preparing the vegetables, use a 4 qt pan or dutch oven and cook 6 strips of bacon until brown and crisp.  Remove the bacon and drain on paper towels.  Add the vegetables to the bacon fat in the pan and saute for 5 minutes.  Then add the clam juice drained from the cans and enough water or additional clam juice to just cover the vegetables and cook until tender.  I always buy an extra bottle of clam juice so I can use all clam juice and no water for cooking the vegetables in as I think it gives it more clam flavor.  For the white sauce I reduced the butter and flour to 1/2 cup and thought it was just right.  At the end, add the minced clams and crumble the bacon in as well.

text:
Excellent chowder.  In addition to the cans of minced clams,  I throw in whatever seafood I have such as tiny scallops or tiny shrimp or some kind of white fish. I buy the bottle of clam juice since I put more ingredients in the pot.  I also put cut up cauliflower instead of the carrots. This makes the chowder nice and thick.  I like to add Old Bay seasoning for taste.  I have to tinker with the right combination of salt, pepper and Old Bay seasoning but once I hit the right mixture, this chowder is wonderful!

text:
I love this recipe, it got gobbled up within a day between my boyfriend and I. I read some of the other reviews and made the following changes:  * I used 32 OZ of whole clams - alot more than the recipe called for (3 large cans of clam). * Fried the veges for a few minutes in bacon fat * Poured in clam juice once the veges softened in the fat (did not need to add extra water because I used so many cans of clam juice). * Crumbled six pieces of bacon into the soup.   The red wine vinegar REALLY did make a difference, brought out the clam flavor!  What I'd do different next time: Use 1/2 cup of flour and 1/2 cup of butter (for less of a buttery taste to the soup).  Yummy! Can't wait to buy some fresh San Franciscan clams for this soup!!

text:
very tasty. here's how i made it healthier: substituted 2% milk for the cream, used light butter and reduced the amount (i think 1 stick is enough to flavor), omitted the salt (there's already enough in the clam juice), and substituted cornstarch for flour (used slightly less than 1/2 the recommended amount). i did sprinkle dried parsley on top, but i was really surprised how much flavor this had for having so few spices. reminds me of home in massachusetts!

text:
Wow! this is "My Best Clam Chowder!" I took a hint from the other reviews, although I kind of winged it from the beginning.  I had a pound of frozen clams in the shell and steamed them in 1/4 tablespoon of butter and 1 teaspoon of minced garlic.  After making sure they were coated,I added 1/4 cup of white wine, covered and steamed for 4 minutes till they opened.  I drained the juice and added the juice from one 10.5 ounce can of minced clams.  Thinking I didn't have enough clam broth, I added 1 1/2 cup of chicken broth to both the drained clam juice and buttery/garlic wine clam juice.  I then fried 3 strips of bacon, removed from pan then added the veggies with the clam broth.  Yes, I sauteed the veggies in the bacon grease, fattening but soooo tasty! (then added the clam broth as instructed)  After whisking the butter, flour and cream mixture, I added all the veggies and clam broth.  I crumbled the bacon and added both the minced and steamed clams, salt and pepper to taste then the red wine vinegar.  This was in one word, FANTASTIC!  It wasn't that hard nor expensive, this is a definite keeper!! Thanks!

Vicky

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is pretty basic, so it's easy to make it your own. I replaced some of the onions with shallots, and I used a half pound of fresh minced clams (instead of canned). Based on other reviews, I replaced the flour with corn starch. The vegetables definitely take longer to cook than it would take you to make the roux, so I would recommend waiting until the potatoes are just getting soft before you start adding flour/corn starch to the melted butter. Also, cooking the veggies in clam juice is definitely the way to go-- it adds the perfect amount of clam flavor.

Things I added: a can of corn, 2 tsp. of fresh, finely chopped sage, a half pound of fresh diver scallops (added to the vegetable mixture when it was almost ready), Old Bay seasoning, Zatarain's Creole Seasoning (just for a little kick), and 1/3 cup of chopped parsley. Excellent!

And one more thing-- I would advise others to add the clams at the last minute, preferably just as you start seasoning to taste. They do get tough.

text:
This was a good starter recipe, but after reading many reviews, I made some modifications as well.  First, like so many others, I browned some bacon, removed the bacon and sauteed the veggies in the grease before adding the water and clam juice.  I also added as many suggested, extra clam juice instead in place of some of the water to increase the flavor.  Seasoned with Old Bay and salt, as well as returning the crumbled bacon to the mix. I used some chopped clams as well as minced to get some larger pieces for texture. Also used cornstarch to thicken instead of flour.  I tripled this recipe for a party and it made a LOT - thankfully I can freeze the leftovers.  Took another reader's suggestion to serve with Cheddar Bay Biscuits from this site, they went well together.  Note this does make a thick chowder, so if you don't like it that way, this isn't the recipe for you.  I will be making this again. Thanks, Sharon.

text:
This was okay. The recipe says to cook the veggies in the clam juice and meanwhile make the cream sauce. The way the recipe was written it makes it sound like the veggies should cook in the amount of time it take to make the cream sauce but they don't; it takes quite a bit longer for the veggies to get soft (I would say about 10-15 mins). Also, I think next time I make it I will use shallots rather than onions because they give cream soups a really nice richness or I will use the onions and add some garlic. Overall, a nice clam chowder recipe, I just need to make some small adjustments the next time I make it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is a great recipe to tweak and edit to your personal tastes.  I started off by frying up four pieces of bacon until crispy, which I then put aside and later crumpled up into the finished soup.  I then added the onion, along with a few cloves of garlic to the fat and fried them up.  Once they were cooked a bit I added the celery along with a bit of old bay seasoning.  Then I added the potatoes, and covered with the clam juice.  I didn't need to add water because I used 5 cans of clams instead of the 3 called for in the recipe.  

I also cut back the amount of butter and flour in the rue to 1/2 cup, and after combining the vegetable mixture with the cream mixture, I added a can of corn, drained, to replace the carrots.  I also seasoned with a bit of parsley.

I almost skipped the red wine vinegar, but I'm glad I didn't.  It's such a small thing, but it makes this whole soup pop!

What a GREAT recipe! I made this for Valentine's day and my husband and 18mth old son could not get enough! I used one can minced clams and one chopped to give a little more texture. Also I've read people mentioning a flour taste. I scaled the recipe to 4 servings and used 1/4c cornstarch instead of the flour. I always find that cornstarch dissolves better in a cream mixture and does not give the flour taste. Thanks for the wonderful recipe!

text:
WOW - is this good!  I used extra clams, just because we like it that way, and substituted balsamic vinegar (I was out of red wine vinegar).  Also, I used 2 bottles of clam juice to simmer the veggies, instead of water. Overall, it was delicious !  Great with french bread & a salad.  Also, you can freeze it before adding the clams.  I defrosts beautifully, reheat and add the clams.  The clams will get tough if cooked too long.

text:
This NW native loved this chowder -my Kentucky husband even loved it - made changes as suggested by other reviews  - cooked 6 slices bacon until crispy - let cool - reserved 2 tablespoons of bacon grease in pan - them added veggies onion, carrots and celery to bacon grease over medium heat a few minutes - then tossed in potatoes and covered in clam juice and proceeded as written until end when adding the clams and red wine vinegar - I added 1/2 tsp old bay along with the salt and pepper then added the crumbled bacon on top   loved loved loved thank you  PIONEERGIRL for this recipe!

text:
A big hit tonight!!!  We did alter it some.  For the chopped potatoes we used a 2 lb bag of southern style frozen potatoes.  We used 2 cans of minced and one can of chopped clams.  We omitted the carrots, and used garlic instead of onions.  We didn't add water and in fact we used a jar of clam juice and a beer.  We didn't have enough half & half so we used milk and thickened it with some corn starch.  Oh, and we also did like the others and used the bacon grease for the celery and garlic and that added great flavor.  So it seems like we altered this recipe a lot.  We sort of did, but we couldn't have made it without the basic recipe, which is similar to a recipe my husband and I used to make 20 years ago, but lost somehow!  Oh, and we served it bread bowls! Thanks!

text:
This is a great clam chowder recipe.  I had misgivings about the red wine vinegar, but like other reviewers, I found it to be an incredible addition.  It added complexity without an actual vinegar taste.  I have made clam chowder my whole life, but from now on, it will always include the vinegar.  I made the recipe basically as written, with the exception of replacing the cream with canned milk. I love real cream, but canned milk avoids some fat calories without a significant loss of flavor.

text:
Excellent chowder.  We simply love Clam Chowder, and like it thick.
First, I want to point out that, contrary to many reviews here, the recipe DOES call for you to use the clam juice.  I did that, and also added some seafood stock, instead of water, to cover the veggies.  Also added a tsp of Old Bay, used 1 c half and half (all I had) and the rest whole milk.  It was still plenty thick enough.

Yum yum, thank you - this is going to become a staple for me.

text:
This recipe was excellent!  To make it a little richer, I sauteed a 1/2 pound of diced bacon, added it to the simmering vegetables and clam stock/water, then deglazed the bacon pan with a little white wine and added it as well.  I then added a little dried thyme, a dash of Worcestershire sauce and a dash of red wine vinegar and let the soup simmer on very low heat for another 1/2 hour.  It really made this rich and hearty - my husband loved it. :)

This is a great recipe. I have made it for the last few xmas eves. I do prefer to fry up some bacon, then save some of the fat to fry the onions in. It adds some flavour. text:
I made this for my parents while they were visiting me in college.  My father is Byzantine Catholic and doesn't eat meat on Fridays, ever, so I was unable to do anything involving bacon.  However, it was pretty darn delicious otherwise, and I plan to make it again.  I used baby clams, but would like to try to use chopped larger clams next time.  We all really liked it.  I think next time I'm going to try to thicken it up just a little bit more... I used fat-free half-and-half, which can sometimes not thicken as well as regular.

Delicious.  I have never made clam chowder before, but am a veteran of bone based soup stock.  I boiled a ham bone for 1 hr, let stock cool and then made this soup.  As a result I was able to reduce the half and half cream by 50% as well as the amount of butter by 25%.  To serve I topped with a tablesppon of crispy bacon bits.  Absolutely delicious and very filling!  Yum!

text:
SO VERY GOOD !!I modified it just a tad...fried about 8 slices of bacon and used the grease to saute the onions, celery and about 8 oz of sliced mushrooms. Then combined sauteed vegetables along with cubed potatoes and diced carrots  and covered it with the juice of (4) 6.5 oz cans of chopped clams and followed the recipe as written from that point on. Crumbled the bacon and used it as a garnishment over individual bowls of chowder at serving time.

I needed meatless and low-fat. I cut the recipe in half. I used 1/2 cup fat free 1/2 & 1/2 and 1 1/2 cups 1% milk. I only used 1/4 cup lt. butter and 1/4 cup flour. I used 2 cans chopped clams (instead of a can and a 1/2). I used some garlic powder while simmering the veggies. Otherwise, I followed the recipe and it was really good and quick and I used ingredients I had on hand.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I am eating and reviewing at the same time. This recipe is AMAZING!! I usually prefer to try a recipe as written, but there were a few modifications that I knew would suit my family's taste. 
- Cook 6 strips of bacon, remove bacon, saute veggies in bacon grease until soft and then add the clam juice (I add a couple cloves of garlic minced to the veggies)
- After adding clam juice, add fresh or dried thyme and extra chicken broth if necessary
- Crumble bacon into soup with clams
I chose to omit the red wine vinegar this time. AMAZING!!! I will make this one again

text:
Just tried it and loved it! Shared it with family and neighbors here in New England and they loved it too. Modifications...used baked blue fish left overs from night before as clam substitution. This gave it a great soft meaty texture and seafood taste minimizing the potential for tough clams. (What else can you do with left over baked fresh caught blue fish your fisherman brings home proudly?) Used 1 can rinsed Great Northern White beans instead of potatoes to keep the carbs count slightly lower. Absolutely delicious...A definite keeper!!!

I made this last night for dinner, it was my first attempt at clam chowder. First off, I left out the carrots/celery per our taste. I cooked the onion in bacon fat, which definitely gave flavor. I wish I would've had bacon (not just fat) to put in the soup, it would've been delicious. I didn't have red wine vinegar, so I used balsamic. After reading reviews, I only used 1/4 cup flour and 1/4 cup butter for roux, and it was perfect consistency. Overall, this was pretty good, I will add more clams next time!!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Best clam chowder I've ever had, HUGE raves from the family, including my picky kids - and my first time making clam chowder! Definitely a keeper.  A very simple, easy recipe to make.  Don't forger to add the minced or chopped clams right before you serve the soup to keep them from getting tough.  Also, I used whole milk instead of half and half, we are slightly lactose intolerant and we didn't need the extra fat (who does?).  If you find that the consistency is thinner than you would like, add a slurry of 2T cornstarch to 2T milk, stir well and add to chowder.  Amazing!  (Next time I will add more clams and more potatoes.) Enjoy!!!

userID:
920146
Display Name:
CMTORIE
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe.  It's definitly a once or twice a year recipe for us though.  I cut up one pound of bacon and pan fry half of it.  I add in the onion, double the carrots and celery and soften them up by frying them in the bacon fat.  Set that aside, and fry up the other half of the bacon (drain some of the fat) and add the potatoes.  After they brown a little bit, I add all the juice from a large 51 oz can of chopped clams (that is enough to cover).  I bring that to a boil, add the veggies back in and simmer.  I follow the rest of the instructions as written except I salt and pepper as I go, rather than at the end, I think it gives a fuller bodied flavor.
Sometimes I need to add some extra milk because it can be a little thick.  The red wine vinegar adds a 'clean' flavor to the soup.  I also add in about 1/2 cup of fresh cut parsley along with all the clams from a 51 oz can (they come in a two pack at Costco).  As others have stated, do this at the last possible moment so the clams don't get chewy!  
A+ recipe!!!

text:
This was delicious!  I came across some fresh clam meat at our fish market, so I was inspiried. First, I sauteed the celery and onion in a little olive oil.  I somehow forgot the carrots, woops.  I (sadly)changed some of the ingredients as we are on a lower cholesterol diet:   used 3T butter, 1/3 cup flour, and a strange combination of skim milk, fat free half and half, and regular half and half.   It was very thick and creamy and I honestly wonder if I could make this soup in the future without the regular half and half and maintain the thickness and creaminess. My family loved it.  In fact, we debated how to make it a "fish chowder" next time.

text:
Very good!  I recalculated the recipe to serve 4 instead of 8 and made a few modifications.  I decided to cut calories and fat by using fat free half and half and cutting back the butter and flour mixture by a few tablespoons.  It still came out extremely rich and thick, to the point where I added some skim milk at the end to thin it out.  Like others, I cooked up some bacon - turkey bacon in the pan before cooking the veggies and clam juice.  Like others, I also used all clam juice instead of water.  Next time I will use even less butter and flour and twice as much clams.

5

This is a good base recipe. I did modify it a bit to suit my personal preferences though. I diced and browned six slices of bacon before adding the veggies. Per the recommendations of some of the other reviewers, I used 5 cups of chopped clams, their juice, and an extra bottle of clam juice instead of the water. I used a mix of milk and half-and-half to cut down on the fat. I will use all low-fat milk and less flour next time--it was too thick or me.

country:
None
text:
This wasn't all that bad, but it could have been better. I made the recipe as written, and here are the changes I'll make for next time. First off, I wouldn't put carrots in it. They didn't taste bad, but I've never had clam chowder with carrots in it. Second, use nothing but clam juice to cover the veggies. Don't use any water. Buy extra clam juice if you have to. This recipes didn't have enough clam flavor for me, and that would certainly help. Lastly, needs WAAAAAY more clams. Like I said, not enough clam flavor. Next time, I'll just 5 cans and see how I like it. Overall, a good base recipe to change to make it better. I just couldn't give it 5 stars with all the changes I need to make.

This was great! I scaled it down some, only used about 1/2 cup of flour and butter, and only used two cans of clams. I used about 2 cups of skim milk, and 2 cups of half & half. userID:
2929684
Display Name:
Julie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This really is outstanding clam chowder! I too followed advice other reviewers had listed. I began with putting the half and half in a small sauce pan on medium-low to warm up. I cooked 6 slices of thick bacon. Reserved some of the bacon grease and sauteed the onion and celery. When it was nicely cooked, I added 2 diced (small dice) russet potatoes and covered the vegetables/potatoes with 1 bottle of clam juice as well as the juice from the 3 cans of clams. I let it cook on a slow boil for about 12 minutes until the potatoes were tender. In a large stock pot, melted the butter and slowly added the flour (I did use what was called for in the recipe). Added some chicken stock to the roux to give the flour some flavor. I had about 1 1/2 cups of stock leftover in the fridge, so I used it up. After whisking the roux for a couple of minutes, I slowly added the warmed half and half.  Whisking quite a bit so I didn't get clumps. I added 2 Tbs of Old Bay Seasoning, salt and pepper. Once all the half and half was in and the seasoning was the way I liked, I added in the potato mixture. I let it heat through, then put in the clams. I used 3 cans of the chopped clams. The clam taste was quite light, so I think I may use 5 cans next time. I tossed in chopped green onions for color, made a grilled cheese sandwich and dinner was done. My husband all but licked his bowl clean. Thank goodness for the grilled cheese or I think he would have! We both really liked this chowder.

This is very good but of course, I made it my own.  I browned cubed bacon ends and set those aside.  I sauteed the carrots, celery and onions along with pressed garlic in a bit of olive oil.  2 cups of potatoes didn't seem like much so I used 4 cups.  I used the clam juice from the cans along with the bottle of clam juice and it covered the vegetables nicely.  

I used 2 cups of half-and-half and 2 cups of 2% milk and it was fine.  I also only used 6 tablespoons of butter.  Gotta cut calories somewhere!

I added the bacon pieces along with the clams at the end.  Also used a pinch of cayenne and Old Bay.  I forgot the red wine vinegar which I think would add another layer of flavor.

As other reviewers mentioned, I also found the taste to be quite "flour-y" and a tad unpleasant.  Next time I will try the cornstarch.  But my husband and mother loved it so it could be just me.

5 stars with some revisions:  I'm from Boston and take clam chowder very seriously!!  This is a good base but lacks a lot of flavor.  First off, I double the canned clams and then add a bottle or two of clam juice instead of water.  I add about 1 to 1 1/2 tsp. of thyme with the vegetables (and leave out the carrots).  After the cream is thick I double the red vine vinegar and add Worcestershire sauce and hot sauce to taste.   This makes it a lot more flavorful in my opinion :)

text:
I followed a number of suggestions and made a couple of changes – but mostly used recipe (adjusted for 12).  I made a day ahead because of my schedule and so many said it was better the next day, but would feel good about serving the day it was made only would simmer about 10 minutes after adding clams and such.  I sautéed the celery and onions in EVOO, added potatoes, juice from 4 cans of whole baby clams, 2 bottles of clam juice, aprox 2 tbs. black pepper and let that simmer until potatoes were tender.  I then melted 1 cup butter and 1 cup of flour {called for 1 cup plus 2 tbs. of each} let cook until flour totally blended and cooked – nice and golden, then I added 4 cups of half and half and 2 cups of low sodium chicken broth (called for 6 cups of h&h and I only had 4) and whisked until thickened.   Added veggie mix, aprox 2 tbs. of sea salt, and 6 drops of Tabasco and simmered until all nicely blended.  I took the pan off the heat, stirred in the 4 cans of clams, 1 pkg of tiny shrimp, and 6 slices of precooked bacon cut into small pieces, covered for 1 hour and then put into the refrigerator.  Next day I put into crock pot and let it heat up gradually and then took crock pot along for lunch – I took along the red wine vinegar along for each to add.  Next will substitute either 1 bottle of clam juice or 1 extra can of clams for part of the chicken broth.  I love all the reviews and suggestions this will go into my favorites.

text:
This chowder recipe is by far better than some restaurant chowders. My family and I love clam chowder and it was a joy too see my family take their first bite and claim it's the best clam chowder they've ever eaten. The only changes I made was to cook 8 slices of bacon in a skillet until browned. I crumbled the bacon and set aside. I then added the carrots, celery, onion and potatoes to the bacon drippings. I cooked it in the dripping for about 3-5 minutes. I then added 1 8 ounce bottle of clam juice, and the reserve clam juice, from 3 cans whole baby clams. I simmered the vegetables until tender. The only changes I made too the white sauce was to use 1 cup of butter, 1 quart half & half  and 1/2 quart heavy cream, and 1 tsp. sugar. Other than that I folllowed the recipe as is. I think the red wine vinegar and some chopped fresh parsley is what sets this chowder a notch above the rest. Thankks for sharing your recipe Sharon. It was a big hit with me and my family.

I have made clam chowder many times and it is usually a dismal failure--probably because i just cannot use butter and cream, it's just too fattening!  this version came out great. my only changes were: fat free evaporated milk in place of 1/2 and 1/2, margarine instead of butter-and i used cornstarch in place of flour (USE LESS CORNSTARCH THAN YOU WOULD FLOUR, MAYBE 1/2) i really thought the vinegar sounded weird but gave it a try and it was fantastic (i used balsamic)not vinegary at all.  super good recipe, thanks!

This chowder was VERY GOOD. Just like anything I have ever had in a restraunt that I have liked. Nice, and thick, and full of flavor. I messed up a bit though. This was the first soup I have ever made, and I over cooked my vegies :(... next time I knwo though. Only cook your vegie's about 10 minutes. They will finish cooking in the soup. I liked the carrots though. I used 3 cans of minced clams, and 2 cans of Chopped clams. I agreed with many of the below reviews, and felt it needed this touch. I can't wait to make this soup again, but not over cook my vegies!

I made this recipe for my son's first birthday party (we had a soup theme).  I used fat free 1/2 & 1/2, omitted the carrots, used chopped rather than minced clams, and replaced water with clam juice per another user's suggestion.  It was a BIG hit with everyone.  Hint: The longer you simmer the mixture before adding the vegetables the thicker it gets.  To thin, add milk as desired.

text:
Oh man, I haven't even added the clams yet, and this is already a 5* recipe!  I only used 1/2 c. of butter, and whole milk instead of the half n half, and it's so rich and delicious you never miss the extra fat.  I did, however, add a couple of strips of uncooked chopped bacon to the butter while it was melting, and let them cook together before adding the flour, and it gives the chowder that little something extra.  It's fab, you have to try!

I added 2 more cans of whole clams, 1 tsp of Phillips Seafood seasoning, which is similar to Old Bay, and also 4 strips of Bacon, two slices of diced smoked ham
I fried the bacon, and used half the butter for the roux. It turned out absolutely wonderful, and everyone loved it. I personally felt I should have omitted the Ham. it added too much salt and took away some clam flavor. Overall, a hit. Will make it again.

userID:

Display Name:
cindy0418
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I did change a few things based on some reviews here which is why I couldn't give it 5 stars. As others suggested, I sautéed 6 chopped up strips of bacon first and then added these back in along with the clams at the end. This gave it a ton of flavor, I think not adding bacon would be a huge miss! I also only used 1/2 cup of flour as I thought 3/4 would thicken the soup too much, 1/2 cup thickened it plenty. I also omitted the carrots, I thought that was just out of place in clam chowder. With these changes - 5 stars!!!

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3318542.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is easy and simple to make. I followed the recipe. The only thing I did different was add bacon. I fried the bacon in a pot and when enough fat has rendered I added the diced carrots, onions and celery. Afterwards, I added the potatoes. I did not use canned clams. I live in Washington State where razor clams can be harvested in our ocean shores. I had caught razor clams that I had cleaned, vacuumed sealed and frozen. It's way better than canned clams. Before adding the roux, I turned off the heat. I added the roux to my veggies instead since it was in a bigger pot. The last were the razor clams so that they were not overcooked. I also added an 8 oz. bottle of Bumble Bee All Natural Clam Juice because I just happen to have it. I also have razor clam juice that I added when I thawed the vacuumed sealed bag. It was creamy and tasted great! Will definitely make it again.

HoustonSue

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it.  So quick, easy and tasty.  Like other reviewers, we enhanced the flavor by adding a bottle of clam juice, and reducing the amount of cream. We ate this as a main dish by also making it lighter and adding more protein.  For the extra protein, add a pound of scallops, shrimp, haddock or cod, or some combination.  To lighten the chowder, replace the quart of half-and-half with 2 just cups of whole milk.  Also, make it lighter by  thickening it with cornstarch dissolved in a bit of water instead of the butter and flour.  Add the cornstarch mixture when you add the seafood at the end.  Simmer everything a few minutes, then slowly add the broth to the milk to raise the temperature of the milk, before combining everything in the pot, and bringing to a last simmer.  I also added 2 packets of Splenda at the end to enhance the natural sweetness of the seafood.  You could also do this with a very small quantity of sugar if you prefer.  It tasted so good, that I never added the vinegar.

text:
My 13 year old son is obsessed with clam chowder and we buy a can for him at least once a week. (Disclaimer) I am NOT a great cook and when I told my son I would make him chowder instead of buying canned he begged me not to. He nixed the bacon idea as well. So, I followed the recipe and took the suggestions to add clam juice instead of water. The flour/roux think was weird and seemed clumpy and gross. I constantly stirred it until it was like a paste and then added the 1/2 and 1/2. Then I stirred for about 10 more minutes. It really thickened up. Poured in the veggies-Seemed like it would be more of a veggie stew but they mixed well with the cream. Added the clams and turned of the heat. Then added the salt and red wine vinegar. So the verdict= It's way better than canned, add more clams then the three cans and maybe the mixture of minced and whole, needs to be a little thicker, (he likes the Monterey stuff which makes a spoon stand up) So until I get The Old Fisherman's Grotto restaurant in Monterey recipe. This is what I will use!

Very good chowder.  Two things to change....use skim milk instead of half and half.  Oberweis fat free milk is the best.  Next, use 2-3 teaspoons Knorr powdered chicken bullion instead of salt.  If the chowder it too thick add more milk.  That's how to make it 5 stars.

text:
This was a fantastic recipe! I made a few modifications that had anyone who ate it licking the bowl and begging for more. I wanted it to be lower in calories as well as with a little more kick to it, so here are the modifications. 

Also, I am a firm believer that clam chowder should always be thick! So when making the roux, take your time and let the cream/butter/flour mixture slowly cook with absolutely constant thickening.

Mods:
1. No potatoes- instead, I used double the carrots, 1.5 times the celery and about 10 cloves of garlic (chopped)
2. More seasoning!- I added garlic powder (I love garlic!), oregano, dill and parsley; all to taste
3. 1/3 less butter- instead of 3/4 cup I used 1/2 cup. It turned out just fine without the 400 extra calories. Next time I may try to get it down to half a cup, but we'll see.
4.LOTS of pepper and half a teaspoon more salt- this technically goes under seasoning, however I feel it deserves it's own bullet. The pepper really gives it a kick to compliment the thick creamy texture and the extra salt was necessary with all the extra vegetables.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe. I actually prefer clam chowder without bacon or ham so finding this was excellent. I did a couple of things differently. Instead of just throwing in all the veggies all at once with the juice, I sauteed the onions in butter first just till soft, translucent & slightly browned. I also sauteed the potatoes in as well (stirring them into onions & butter for about 3 min). I then added the clam juice, carrots, celery & topped it off with about 2 cups of HOT water & a tsp of THYME. That cooked for a few min while I made the roux. I love it creamy so I added a half pint of heavy cream. I also used 2 cans of whole baby clams and 2 cans of minced clams as well as more potatoes than the recipe called for. IT WAS SO GOOD!

Display Name:
Hossein Asgharian

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did the bacon thing as most reviewers had suggested. Only thing I want to mention is this: After adding the flour to melted butter, cook it on medium low heat for a few minutes (10 or less). This remove the raw smell of flour. Also, after adding the half-n-half the flour was made into clots and I only got rid of them by transferring the mixture into a bowl and using the mixer on it for a couple of minutes. That made it totally smooth and nice. As for the vegetable part, next time I'll drain the broth, keep it and put the cooked pieces (except the potato) in the food processor for a few seconds to grind them well, and return to the broth. That'll give the soup a smoother look.

userID:
1304877
Display Name:
SUIW
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1505043.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely the best homemade chowder, and practically beats any I've tried anywhere else! I followed the recipe to a T, with only 3 minor changes. First, I sauteed bacon with the onions, then added the rest of the veggies and liquid and simmered all together. Secondly, I didn't have half and half, but I had whole milk on hand, and that worked just as well. Everything came together perfectly!! Third, I added corn, because I like corn in my chowder and so does my family. I doubled the recipe and it makes a big pot that feeds a family of 6 adults, plus leftovers. Make sure to cook the roux a bit before adding the cream to cook away the flour taste. And the longer you cook the cream with the roux, the thicker your base will be. My chowder was perfect!!! And who would've thought that red wine vinegar (the secret ingredient) would have brought all the flavors together so wonderfully! This has to be the most easiest and super tasting chowder ever.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2013-02-05T14:58:54.02
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
6731829
Display Name:
Ccooks
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
25
favoritesCount:
36
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/806257.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe as is, is quite bland, but a good base to season as you would like. There are several good suggestions as to how to perk this recipe up (tsp onion and/or garlic powder, etc.). Clam juice itself is not overly tasteful. Instead of water or additional clam juice, I'd cover the cooking vegetables with a quart of chicken broth. Also, a good roux takes takes a few minutes and patience (the flour & butter step). Alternatively, I would definitely go with the bacon suggestion: Dice up 4 strips of bacon and fry until golden brown, add 1/2 cup flour. and mix together, browning slightly - then add gradually add the cream, etc. Good luck!

text:
Very, very good clam chowder.  I followed previous advice and fried 3 thick cut slices of bacon in my pan before adding the veggies, etc.  I don't recommend any more than 3 because the soup might come out greasy.  As it was, it came out perfect.  I thinned it out with skim milk because I like it thinner.  The red wine vinegar is a MUST HAVE.  Don't skip it!  It adds brilliant flavor.  Definitely one of the freshest, best clam chowders I have ever eaten.  Every time a friend of mine gets sick, this is what she wants me to make her.  Thank you for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe is fairly simple yet the results are amazing.  I was a little skeptical of the vinegar but it adds a richness and no vinegary taste at all.  I've started to use this trick in many other creamy soups.  After making this just once my family was hooked and begs me to make it over and over.  The only change I've made is to use 1% milk or even fat-free evaporated milk in place of the cream to lighten it a bit - can't tell the difference.  Perfect for dreary, cold days but I've also made it in the summer!  Grab some crusty bread and you're set!

Display Name:
Annette Platzner
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1529962.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I been looking for a good clam chowder recipes well this is it! I did it change a few minor things I just can't seem to help myself. on the advice of other reviewers I cooked 3 slices of bacon in my stock pot, then took the bacon out to drains and crumble in later. when I added the clam juice and water I also added in some time and old bay seasoning (next time I will use bottled clam juice instead of water). I didn't want to use a separate pan so any microwave safe bowl I added the potter and the flower and cooked it together until thoroughly nick n about a lease then I added the half and half into the bowl using a whisk. then I dumped the mixture into the stock pot with the vegetables and water and juice. I cooked the whole thing on medium heat until nice and hot thick but not boiling. then I added back in the bacon and the clams. I used 2 cans of chopped clams and 1 can of baby clams. I didn't have any red wine vinegar but I will try it next time it was still amazing without it!

text:
Excellent recipe. I've just finished making it for the first time, and will make it again. When trying new recipes, I generally do not make any changes; however, I did make four tiny changes to this one. Instead of water, I used store-bought vegetable broth, about 1 cup more potato, a clove of garlic, and 1 additional can of minced clams (because they were buy 1 and get 1 free). I don't care for strong fish or seafood flavors, and even with the extra can of clams, the flavor did not overwhelm my palate. Because I try to stick to a mostly vegetarian diet, I chose to bump up the overall flavor of the chowder with vegetable broth instead of water as directed in the recipe or sauteing in bacon as suggested by other reviewers.

text:
I have followed the recipe as is, but have now tweeked it quite a bit.  My first complaint is that it is not clammy enough.  I add an 8 oz bottle of clam juice and 2 other cans of chopped clams. I also add bay leaves, a clove of chopped garlic, a pinch of thyme leaves.  Some white wine adds some good flavor as well. Cooking on the stove doesn't seem to soften the potatoes enough, so I now put it in a crock pot to simmer to enhance the flavor and cook the vegetables more.  Much better!

text:
My husband gave this five stars, I would give it about three as it lacked some flavor until you put the vinegar in. Then it tasted like vinegar. :) But hubby says it's one of the better clam chowders he has ever had. 

I like my soup/chowder to be chunky so I sliced carrots and celery and left my onion pieces big. It ended up tasting very floury despite following directions to the letter, so I added milk at the end to  balance it out and make it less dense (the thicker cut vegetables could be to blame for this too). 

Definitely will make again, if only to keep husband happy.

This was a great recipe. Delish!!!  Things I did differently was to first take 2 strips of bacon and cook them in the skillet.  I then took them out and drained the fat -- then cooked the veggies. This is the best clam chowder I've ever made. It's not the best I've eaten, but deserves better than four stars, so I gave it five. I minced all the veggies (and added 1/2 cup leek) and cut the potatoes into small cubes. text:
I finally got tired of shelling out money for canned soup, and I am soo glad I found this recipe! We love clams in our house and the heartier the better, so I added lots of chopped clams. I sauteed my veggies in the bacon fat, but I wasn't really feeling the bacon in my soup, so I left it out. I also didnt have clam juice, so I added fish sauce! I know that sounds weird, but it worked. The soup was a little thick, so I thinned it out a tad.  This recipe is so good, I dont think I ever buy canned chowder again. I didnt know about the veggies, but except for chopping the carrots extra small (hiding them from my 5yod who will not touch them) they were no problem at all and added great flavor. perfect for a chilly day in the house!

Great recipe!  Better than most restaurant versions. I used Bar Harbor Chopped Clams, substituted 2% milk for half-and-half, and reduced butter to 1/4 cup. Still thick and delicious! Added red pepper flakes and fresh Italian flat leaf parsley to taste at the end when I added the clams.  Definitely don't skip the red wine vinegar and you will love this recipe.  Yummmm!!

This was very good, although I did make a few changes. Started out by cooking 4 slices chopped bacon ands then used the fat to sauté the celery and onion. Left out the carrots, and used at lease 2x the amount of clams. I did use some whole ( canned) clams which were  little "chewy" but not too bad, and gave a little more texture . I also seasoned with a bay leaf and some thyme. At the end, garnished with the cooked crispy bacon. Def. Will make again!

I agree with the title of this recipe, this is the best clam chowder ever!! My adaptions are for a 12 serving recipe. I used 1 stick of butter, 2 cups of half and half and 4 cups of 1% milk. userID:
6025545
Display Name:
kittycat824
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent starting point, but could use a little tweaking here and there. I didn't use 3/4 cup butter only 1/2 and decided to use 2 cups of half and half and 2 cups low fat milk. I skipped the bacon browning part that everyone is recommending since it seems a bit unhealthy for me and still came out fine. Be sure to use all the clam juices from the clams and omit the water entirely. Instead of using flower, I used 1/2 cup of corn starch that made the chowder nice and thick! I also decided to skip the onions and use onion powder instead. The red wine vinegar is a nice touch I added about 3-4 tablespoon, make sure to add a little at a time otherwise it may be overwhelming for your taste.

text:
I made this for dinner the other day & it was pretty good! I used 3 cans of whole baby clams instead of minced, I also used a bottle of clam juice instead of water. Before I started the chowder I cooked up some hickory flavored bacon, then placed them on a plate & crushed them up. I also put the bacon grease in the pan with the potatoes, carrots, etc to add flavor & sprinkled a little garlic powder in there. I added a tiny bit of cornstarch to the half & half mixture cause I like a thick chowder! It still seemed to need a little more flavor, but it was still really good! Next time I make it I think I'll use heavy cream instead of the half & half & add real garlic to it instead of powder. Over all very good chowder!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was an excellent chowder!  I tweaked it a bit to match our preferences, and I have received numerous compliments on it as my husband took it to work to share with his co-workers.  I added bay leaves to the simmering onions, celery, and potatoes in clam juice (and eliminated the carrots based on personal preference).  I also added salt & pepper at that stage.  For the creamy base, we like a really thick chowder, so I used 1 container of 1/2 and 1/2 and heavy whipping cream.  When that wasn't thick enough, I took a small container of heavy whipping cream and added about 1/2 - 3/4 of a cup of cornstarch.  I whipped it together then added to the creamy base, and the thickness was awesome!  I also used a LOT more clams than recommended (8 cans) and used red potatoes for color. Thanks for the recipe - I have been a clam chowder fan my whole life but never had the courage to try and make it myself.

Wow... I have never made a creamed based soup or chowder before and I have to say this recipe is easy and great!  For those rookies, just be patient with the thickening of the cream... it takes a good 10 minutes before it really starts to thicken.  You do not need to add heavy cream, the half & half makes it plenty thick.  The only thing I did different was I added some minced garlic and instead of the vinegar I used port wine!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this so many times over the last two fall and winter seasons and I can't believe I have never rated it.  This clam chowder is fabulous - made it as written once and it was just way too rich for us but I still can't give it any less than five stars because it's just as good with 1% milk and one-third the amount of butter. Usually when you take away the "good" stuff and replace it with healthier options, you may be left with a so-so product, but not with this chowder. It is still rich and creamy.  I always use regular milk instead of cream (I've used whole milk, 2% and 1% - what ever I have on hand) and you really can't tell a difference.  I only use 1/4 cup of butter (half a stick as opposed to 1 and 1/2 sticks) and 1/2 cup of flour. Always make sure to cook your flour in the butter for a minute or two to cook out the "flour" taste.  I usually add 4 cans of chopped (not minced) clams and boil my veggies in the clam juice and vegetable broth for added flavor. The red wine vinegar makes all the difference. This recipe is so good. Thank you Pioneergirl!

text:
I made a few small changes. 1)like someone else suggested, i only used clam juice, no water 2) i reduced the butter and half half by a third to cut down on fat, and substituted the rest of the cream with milk. 3) i can not have gluten, so like most recipes that call for a thickner, i substituted cornstarch. 4) and most importantly i added a clove of garlic.  after tasting the completed recipe, i felt it still needed something and garlic did the trick.  i read many reviews that said bacon was added, but we don't eat bacon, and felt the garlic added that last needed flavor.

country:
None
text:
I specifically chose this clam chowder recipe because it did not rely on bacon for flavor.  I cut back on both the butter and flour using only 1/2 cup of each, and it worked just fine. I did saute fresh minced garlic in the butter before adding the flour.  In place of the half and half, I used milk. The recipe was still rich and thick with these cuts in fat. Next time I wouldn't add the carrots just because I don't think that they really belong in there.  I was timid about adding the vinegar...tasting the soup before and in between adding a little vinegar at a time, just to make sure it would be ok, but not to worry...adding the full amount of vinegar adds to the flavor, but you can't tell that there is vinegar in there.  The type of canned clams used were Baby Clams-Fancy Whole, and the size was just right.  This is the first time I've tried making clam chowder, and we really liked this.

text:
I've made this recipe many times and it never gets old. I also fry bacon (added later) and then saute the onion and celery in the bacon fat in the soup pot. I add a bottle of clam juice plus the drained juice from the canned clams to the liquid. I also add some Old Bay and garlic powder to the mix. I let the mixture cook sometimes for a few hours then thicken with a cornstarch/broth mixture. I know I have changed the original recipe, but in my opinion, what makes this recipe a 5 star on its own for the submitter is the quart of half and half and the red wine vinegar which are the magic ingredients. Also, adding the clams right before serving time is essential so they remain tender. Truly delicious restaurant quality soup. The entire pot is gone in 2 days. Thank you.

I used 2 tablespoons of reserved bacon fat to lightly sauté the celery, carrots, onion and potatoes before adding. This chowder is so delicious and works well with clams and other seafoods. Very good. But not what I was hoping for. It didn't really taste like clam chowder from a nice restaurant, like I was hoping. I think I will leave out the bacon next time. Mine was VERY bacony! I also used clam juice instead of water.  Also, it makes a LOT, I took leftovers to the inlaws. :)

text:
Excellent recipe.   I read the reviews and did the following.  I purchased OM bacon crumbles, 2 jars of clam juice, and 2 cans of diced potatoes... I just added the onions, carrots, and celery to the skillet as per the directions and then sprinkled 1/2 of the bacon crumbs on top and poured the clam juice to cover all - I did not use water.  I also have made this recipe using corn starch instead of the flour - I find that it is a creamier texture... I add the potatoes in toward the end since they just need to heat through and then add the clams... the vinegar is a must. Top with the remaining 1/2 of the bacon crumbles... FABULOUS with crusty french rolls.  MMmmm good!

None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty good. Like others, I used all clam juice, no water, & I rendered 3 slices of bacon and used the grease to saute the veggies, omitting the carrots (I've never had carrots in my clam chowder before)  This added a ton of flavor.  The vinegar is definitely what makes this recipe!  It instantly changed from potato soup to a classic flavored clam chowder.  I love rich, creamy recipes, but the half and half was WAY too thick & creamy for this one.  I mixed 2% milk into my bowl and it was then perfect.  I will use 4 cups 2% milk and .5 cup cream next time.  Throw the crumbled bacon in at the end, even if it's not "classic" clam chowder fodder, it's too good to waste!
