text:
This clam chowder recipe is delicious, but there is no need to pack in all of those calories.  I followed the recipe closely, except I used 5 cans of clams, omitted the butter altogether and used all skim milk in place of the half and half.  To create the desired thickness, I simply added 3 teaspoons of corn starch.  At the end the red wine vinegar and some fresh chopped cilantro really gave an awesome tasty touch!!  Hubby loved it, will make this again!

text:
This recipe is so similar to the one I have been using for years. I must admit I like the addition of the vinegar. I left out the carrots but added a few things from my recipe like thyme, a sprinkle of dried dill weed and Old Bay seasoning. I also cut down the fat by using fat free half & half and also using 2% milk. I cooked the veggies down in some clam juice instead of bacon grease. I use Turkey bacon fried really crisp to crumble on top. Living so close to the ocean, we have several Seafood Markets around so it's great to be able to make Clam Chowder with fresh whole baby clams added at the last moment before serving. A splash of hot sauce is just the thing to set it off just right!!

Well, I am really not sure how to rate this one. I have lived in New England my entire life so I think I expected this to be the type of chowder we have around here. It was a very basic recipe, but the taste just didn't do it for me. It was thick & creamy, but didn't taste very much like anything but cream & butter. I missed the clam taste that I am used to from the chowders around here. So, I may make this again but I would add more clam juice and maybe cut back on the half & half a little. I did add bacon to my chowder but left out the carrots, because carrots in chowder just seemed a little odd to me.

userID:
2950116
Display Name:
RandyLee
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/116215.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I live in Santa Cruz California, and have tried clam chowders from up and down the west coast, this rivaled any chowder I have eaten anywhere.  I did make a few changes.  First I cut up four thick slices of bacon and fried them up adding the potatoes a few minutes before the vegis and clam juice.  I replaced water with more clam juice, to cover the vegis, and left out the carrots.  I also switched flour with corn starch.  I used one pint half and half, and one pint heavy whipping cream.  Next time I might use just a quart of heavy whipping cream.  I can't wait to try it again, next time I am going to make some home made sour dough bread bowls, instead of store bought ones.

Be sure to add the vinegar...it really does make the flavors sparkle!

text:
This was the best clam chowder I've ever had. Everyone loved it. I did what a lot of other people did and browned some bacon, mixing the fat in along with the vegetables. I did not include the carrots since I've never really seen carrots in clam chowder. The red wine vinegar added a whole new level of flavor that was evident the moment I poured it into the pot. I also added a dash of onion and garlic powder. Oh, and I did not have half and half so I ended up using heavy cream. This without a doubt made the chowder extremely fatty and rich, but it did not take away from the flavor. However, next time I will be using half and half.

text:
Revised review today so I do not have to keep giving out the recipe:
I have perfected this recipe with suggestions and use a crock pot to simmer. If you are not worried about calories, as we make this every Christmas Eve; here is my modifications. 
Cook the bacon on low, saving the bacon grease,
Saute the onions in butter and garlic,
Add the bacon and a little grease, and the clam juice from the cans, with the veggies for 15 minutes on low to medium, depending on your stove.
In another pan, melt the butter and whisk 1/2 cup flour and 1/4 corn starch,
add 1/2 quart of half and half and 1/2 quart whipping cream,
place the veggies and bacon(everything from the other pan) in crock pot and pour the sauce over the veggies. You may need to add a little half and half or whipping cream as desired while simmering.
Allow to simmer in crock pot on low for two hours (check veggies to know when ready); adding the following ingredients for taste:
1. 1/2 teaspoon of Old Bay seasoning,
white pepper and black pepper to taste,
a little thyme to taste,
a little more garlic-just a little,
a little garlic salt -(avoid regular salt) very little is too much,
a little onion salt,
add key ingredient-liquid smoke to taste (use carefully, start with a little, let simmer, check later, add more if needed, for desired taste).
*If you do not like the taste, add a little more whipping cream.
In two hours, when you are ready to eat, add the clams and add the red wine vinaigrette to taste . You will know when

text:
Very good chowder!  Although ... and this is hardly a criticism (more a caution) ... I really don't think this stuff would be hurt if you substituted whole milk for at least some of the half-and-half.  I doubled the recipe (for my weekly lunch-at-the-office supply) and it just felt WRONG dumping that half-gallon of half-and-half into the pot!  I also doubled (or tripled) the amount of clams and clam juice.  Glad I did that, because the clam flavor seems to have a hard time getting through the cream....

(Guilty) yum....

text:
My, oh my!  This was awesome!  My family devours this each time I make it.  I have to wonder if maybe some of the reviewers who stated that it was bland and needed more clam flavor noticed that you cook the veggies in the drained clam juice?  We had no problems tasting the flavors.  Also, if you cook the flour for about a minute or so before stirring in the cream, you shouldn't be able to taste the flour.  I did leave out the carrots just because that's not something that we associate with clam chowder.  Also, if you're in a hurry or out of potatoes (like I was), I found that frozen Ore-Ida O'Brien potatoes make a great substitution.  Just don't cook them too long or they will turn to mush.

Really, really, really good chowder!  Very thick, rich, and hearty.  I followed the recipe exactly except for two minor changes: I used 1/2 cream and 1/2 milk (I guess I used more of the 1/2 and 1/2 in my coffee than I realized!) and I added one can of tiny shrimp (I had clam chowder with shrimp in Newport, OR and decided all clam chowder should be made that way).  The red wine vinegar absolutely makes this recipe!  Hubby  (who is a clam chowder connoissuer) says this recipe is a keeper for sure!

GREAT! I tweaked it up just a little bit.  I followed the other suggestions and used clam juice in place of the water to cook the veggies. Also... Kosher salt, and 1 t. Johnny's Seafood Seasoning. 
Very smooth...very good!

text:
WOW!!!!  I have to admit this was the best clam chowder I have ever made.  I decreased the butter to 1/2 cup, used 1% milk and added a dash of nutmeg.  I'm always in a rush--so after cutting the onions, celery and carrots with my Borner slicer, fast easy and wonderful, I just added hash browns (the cubed kind, not the grated) to the vegetables for the last minute or two and then added it all to the soup.  So fast, easy and clean.  I will definately make this chowder again!!!  Even my picky eaters loved it and my husband had to fight with the teenage boys for the left-overs.

text:
Took some advice from other reviewers. I cooked 6 pieces of back until crisp in a large skillet. I then sauteed all the veggies in that grease and the in a small minced clove of garlic before adding the clam juice. I had two 10oz cans of baby whole clams, so I used the clam liquid from the cans and one 8oz bottle instead of the water. The only other change was to add the crumbled bacon in right before serving and add a little extra seasoning including a little thyme.

text:
This is by far one of the best clam chowders I’ve ever tasted and I’ve had clam chowder up down both coasts. Simply follow the recipe but brown some bacon before hand, add the veggies to bacon fat, and then continue with the normal recipe. Throw the chopped bacon in the soup and keep some for a topper. I stole this from a few other reviewers and it makes a world of difference. Plus I only add one can of minced clam, the other 2 are chopped. Bigger better flavor

text:
Been using this recipe for years. It's the best. I always double the recipe and make two modifications. First I buy a 51 oz can of clams, 23 oz clams the remainder clam juice. Second I buy a 1# jar of clam base  and add it as needed to boast the flavor. Do not add salt as the base is salty.
PS Costco sells the clams in a 2/ pack.

userID:
4150171
Display Name:
christie
isPro:

12
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious as written.  And absolutely delicious with a few changes.
1.  fry up some bacon and drain, retaining the fat in the pot.
2. saute onion, garlic, celery and potatoes for a couple of minutes.
3.  Cover with clam juice and simmer until potatoes are al dente.  About 10-15 minutes.
4.  Add salt, pepper, Old Bay, a few drops of Liquid Smoke, and 1tbsp red wine vinegar.
5.  In a separate pot, melt 1 stick of butter...whisk in 1/2 c. flour. Stir constantly for about 5 minutes.
6.  Add about 4 c. 1/2 and half.  Continue whisking until thickened.
7.  Add the cream sauce to the onion/garlic/celery/ clam juice.
8.  Stir.
Add clams and crumbled bacon and simmer for about 2 minutes.
Correct seasonings.
Add parsley.
Turn off your stove.  You're done.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The chowder is fine except that it requires so much thickener. Many people think a spoon needs to stand up straight in a bowl of real New England clam (or fish) chowder. Please, cut out (or cut way back) on the flour. "Thick" chowder is for tourists.  Real New Englanders think the starch from the potatoes will be thickener enough, or maybe just a little flour, or even better,  just a little corn starch for a gluten-free version.

userID:
513916
Display Name:
Jenelle D
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
151
favoritesCount:
535
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/98462.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I make this in my instant pot with the following modifications: I do cut up about 12 strips of bacon and sautee first (sautee mode) - remove those and put in a bowl to drain on paper towel then double up the veggies (carrots, onion and celery) and sautee those in the bacon grease until slightly softened.  Add the clam juice from six cans (doubled that part too) to the veggies and deglaze the pot.  Add the potatoes and add just enough water to cover (about 2 cups of water in my 6 qt pot).  Set to manual (pressure cook) for 8 minutes then do a quick release.  While it's cooking I make the roux but I do NOT double the roux - it's plenty thick enough made per the recipe.  Once the pin drops on the Instant Pot I slowly add the roux, the salt and pepper (to taste) and vinegar then the claims.  It cuts down on cooking time overall and is so good!

I changed a bit with this one, and WOW I think this is a new favourite.  Heats up really well for a couple of days so its great for meal prep if that's your thing.

-Added 2 TSP dry mustard and a whack of black pepper

text:
This recipe is the absolute best.  My entire family loves clam chowder and we all agreed that it is some of the very best we have ever made.  I added sautéed bacon, fresh thyme and bayleaf and used chicken broth instead of water.  I still felt like it was a little flat on seasoning, so I also added a chowder spice base and a little red pepper flakes and it gave it just the punch it needed.  It is a very thick recipe, so for our own personal taste/thickness, I added more chicken broth at the end.  Great recipe, you will love it!

text:
This recipe is SUPER solid! That being said, it can be bland if you don't use a lot of salt and pepper. I read the comments after I made it (rookie mistake) and here's what I'll think about trying next time:
- Bacon grease & bacon
- Let the roux cook down more
- 1/2 teaspoon of Bay Seasoning
- 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder
- Chopped clams instead of minced clams
- 1/2 teaspoon garlic salt
- Chives
- 1/2 teaspoon of liquid smoke
- Fresh grilled corn cut off the cob
- White pepper
- Saute the onion in the bacon fat, LOW & SLOW
- Clam juice - no water
- Dried minced onion?
- Nearly carmelize all the veggies first
- Parsley
- Celery salt
- Thyme

Made the recipe for 24 servings. Cooked a pound of bacon and started the veggies in the bacon grease for about 5 minutes before adding potatoes and covering with the clam juice. I cooked the rue on low heat for about 10-15 minutes to get rid of the flour smell and taste.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We loved this.  I started with the 5 strips of bacon.  Drained some of the grease and cooked the vegetables in what grease was left.  I poured the liquid from the 3 whole baby clam cans  over the veggies plus a bottle of clam juice.  I added a bay leaf to that.  I made the roux with 1 stick of butter and 3/4c flour--that was perfect.  Then a quart of 1/2 1/2 plus a touch of milk.  Added garlic salt, onion powder, a bay leaf.   Next time I will reduce the celery and carrots to 1/2 c each.  Flavor was perfect for my clam chowda experts!!!!

text:
I have made this twice now, and this recipe is a keeper! The second time, I made some tweaks.  Used gluten free flour. No difference.  My own spices that I added... a few shakes of smoked paprika.  A couple shakes Old Bay.  a pinch of dill.  My husband said, that recipe was good, but whatever you did really put it over the top.  The family thinks I slaved over this, and it is a piece of cake to make... chop and boil some vegetables, make a white sauce, add clams, vinegar and stir it all up.   One typo I noticed is that the list called for three cans, and the recipe seemed to call for one.  I added three and it was good.

text:
I made this for the first time on Christmas Eve. My whole family the guinea pigs. I gave three stars because of the ease and the base isn’t bad but there is room for improvement. I used whole clams and chopped myself. There was too much flour. A rue is 1:1 but this was a little much. There wasn’t enough clam flavor, I’ll add clam stock next time. I’ll probably try whole milk rather than half and half as this is thick! The veggies were good and held up well. The carrots were a different spin but tasty. All in all this is a solid base to build on. Plus my family ate it!

city:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe  and loved it.  AND for all those bacon crazy people out there, my humble opinion is that if I wanted bacon chowder I would have made bacon chowder.  I LOVE the taste of clams, and bacon only detracts from this.  I don't recommend bacon.  I made even more clam flavor by using the recommended amount of clams, but chopped instead of minced.  In addition, I made my own clam juice by steaming 3 lbs of clams. I did not add carrots.  This has been my Christmas Eve tradition for 4 years, and I hope to continue for many many more. YUMMY!!!  Serve with warm sour dough bread and a light salad and get smiles!!!

text:
No bacon. I make New England clam chowder all of the time and the first thing is to brown bacon and add butter. When Bacon is done you crumble it and then cook the celery and onions until translucent, then you add the clam juice and potatoes and seasonings and bring to boil for about 10 minutes then you add one large ear of corn off the cob where the kernels had been roasted for about 10 minutes along with the clams, stir all together and then add cream and bring to a slow boil, then you mix corn starch and water together and pour into hot soup and blend to thicken. You are missing all of this and therefore the soup is marginal. The bacon is the real key to the flavor you get in restaurants and my recipe comes from the Cliffs of Main recipe which I got off the internet and have used it for years.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-10-28T22:38:01.76
helpfulCount:

country:
None
text:
The better the clams the better the soup will be. I also would recommend adding half the clam water from the cans of you go that route, otherwise it doesn't turn out very thick and you'll have to add more flour or corn starch to make it thicker. This goes great with bread bowls if you can find them! 
Also, this recipe makes a lot so if it's just a couple eating this, you're going to have leftovers, lots, and they'll likely go bad before you can eat it all. 
So half it! 
However, if you're cooking for a group you'll be good :)

text:
I've made it like the recipe calls for and it is excellent. Next I did what a few of the other reviews said, added bacon, garlic etc. I also have had cream to use so I really go for the extra calories then :)  I like to also add cod fish to mine as well. After you make the bacon, fry up a little cod (but you can just put it in raw as well if you give it enough time to cook) and my kids barely know its there, mixes in with the potatoes. After its done cooking, I sprinkle over the top the crumbled bacon and some diced parsley or chives for extra appeal. I like to make it a full and heavy meal. My husband, born & raised in Maine, loves all of this, says its much better than a restaurant.

userID:

Display Name:
Gw Max
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3627704.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love New England Clam Chowder ( not a fan of Manhattan Clam Chowder)

I think it should be thick & full of clams.

I omit the carrots, there should not be orange things floating in  Clam Chowder & they add no flavor.

Use 3 cans minced clams + 2 cans of chopped or baby clams.

Also, bottled clam juice in place of water is a must.

The 6 strips of crumbled bacon is a very nice touch (as others have mentioned)

I dice the potatoes incited of cubing them so they fit on a soup spoon better. 

Serve with a side of Oyster cracker for anyone that would like them.

Also, make your own Half & Half (1/2 heavy cream + 1/2 whole milk)

text:
I think this is a great starter recipe for a basic, no frills, clam chowder. 

The instructions don’t really elaborate on the butter and flour phase, but I let it cook a little while until it is almost a roux which thickens the half and half nicely....  the recipe as written was too thick for me, but was still delicious.

I’ve made it three times so far, but after testing it a few times I’ve decided I like adding an extra 2 cups of half and half.

text:
Excellent recipe. I made three changes but only due to personal preference 1) I always saute my onion and veg in margarine or olive oil before adding to liquid. In this case I sautéed them in becel olive oil margarine then added the clam juice and followed recipe as is until my next change  2) I found I had to use at least another 2 cups of milk as it was too thick for my liking. I will keep this recipe handy and have marked my changes but will also either use less flour or plan to use more milk in the roux from the start .3)  I added Old Bay Seasoning as I do to most of my seafood recipes, just gives it that extra little kick. great recipe and the red wine vinegar is a special touch - what about red wine??? Hmmm.

text:
I followed the recipe as written and came out with a lbland tasting chowder.  I went back again and with improvements, turned out fine. If using this recipe, I would follow user suggestions and sauté garlic with the veggies, add clam juice instead of water, reduce flour to 1/2 cup and use spices (old bay, thyme, white pepper) I also think that this needs some heat so I would use a little cayenne or chili powder.  We prefer fresh lemon juice with seafood so we subbed that for the vinegar.

Excellent clam chowder recipe...I have dairy intolerant family members so had to swap the dairy...for the  cream I used full fat coconut milk (14 oz.) + 2 cups of homemade chicken broth and reserved all the water & oil from the smoked clams about 1 cup worth.  Added 2 pieces of bacon diced & some bacon grease to soup base. For the butter I used coconut oil. Delicious, rich and comforting on a cold dreary day.

city:

text:
Outstanding. Foolproof! This was my very first attempt at clam chowder, and I'm so glad I used this recipe!! I followed the original with modifications based on the suggestions of other commenters: 1) cooked roux with half butter, half bacon grease and made sure to cook it all down to avoid too much of a flour flavor, 2) used clam juice (and chicken broth) in lieu of water, and 3) seasoned with Old Bay, onion powder, and garlic salt. The red wine vinegar put the flavor over the top!!! Served with sourdough bread. Incredible!

userID:
2384072
Display Name:
Shar
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
76
favoritesCount:
228
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! Boiled the vegetables (1 onion, 3 carrots, 3 celery stalks, 6 small red potatoes) in all the clam juice (from 4 cans minced and 2 cans whole) and about a cup of water to cover everything. I also added 2 handfuls of prepared crumbled bacon since its all I had on hand and some dried thyme (about a tsp) from my garden. I mixed up the flour with the cold half and half and then added it to the butter. When it became a roux, I added it to the veggies and let that combine and heat up before adding the reserved clams and some black pepper.  We omitted the vinegar. Wonderful! This will become a regular in our house.

.....Update: Today we had another snow day, so we made this again. This time I tried it with the vinegar. It surprised me how flavorful the soup became with a small amount of vinegar. Add it, don't hesitate.  You'll be glad you did.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Stop reading now if you're someone who doesn't think changes should be reviewed!  :-)

I used stock that I'd made from mussels shells and shrimp tails (from the evening before) in place of the  water, but I would substitute clam juice if I didn't have that.  Water just doesn't seem right.  I also cooked up 4 pieces of bacon, removed them and sauteed the veggies in the drippings for a moment before adding the stock.  (Before adding the veggies and clam juice/stock into the white sauce, I skimmed off some of the fat that came to the top, just to cut down a bit on the calories.)  I added the pepper but left out the salt so that people could add their own amount at the table.  Served this with salad and crusty bread - great winter night dinner!

This is a very rich soup, gourmet quality

text:
This was a great clam chowder soup!  I followed other suggestions.  I cooked 4 pieces of bacon and used the grease to brown the onions and cook the carrots and celery.  Then I added the potatoes and a can of corn.  Cooked all of this with the clam juice from 4 cans on medium while making the roux.  I did not add other spices, just salt and added the vinegar at the end.  Next time I would add Old Bay.  GREAT SOUP.  I don't think the adding of bacon or corn alters the recipe that greatly, just makes it better.

text:
Based on a number of other reviews, I added three rashers of bacon and then cooked the vegies in the bacon fat. I also used  1/2t Old Bay Spice, three cloves of garlic, 1t Cholula sauce, 1/2t onion powder and white pepper instead of black.
Finally, I used gluten free all purpose flour with 2t of cornstarch. That might have been a little heavy handed with the cornstarch. I thought it messed the texture up just a bit.

I thought the vinegar was a perfect addition. Overall, I thought  this was yummy but not exceptional. My guy loved it, so four stars.

text:
This is a great recipe! I changed just a couple things after reading the reviews: I diced and cooked a few strips of bacon first, took the bacon out, and cooked the veggies in the bacon grease. Then I cooked the potatoes separately first (mostly par-boiled), then used chicken broth instead of water to cover & cook the veggies and potatoes before adding the roux.  When it was finished cooking, it was a tad too runny for my taste, so I used a potato masher to roughly mash some of them to thicken it up. Added the diced cooked bacon back into the chowder, and I also added some hot sauce to taste at the end. It was delicious!

Display Name:
Brianne Barkley
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7321817.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made my rendition of this recipe probably 20 times by now and it is really great. As others said, you definitely want to add the bacon step in. I use 4 strips, chopped, and set aside the cooked bacon for topping the soup with. I add two bottles of clam juice and top the rest of it off with vegetable broth to cover. 

I also prefer a less chunky soup so I run the hand blender through it before adding the clams, leaving some chunks. This also thickens it - so all I need then is to whisk about 3T of butter into 2 cups of half/half and mix that in to get it to the right consistency. All that butter is an unneeded and fattening step to me! 

Do not skip the red wine vinegar though! I put the bottle right on the table to drizzle in each bowl.

Display Name:
DEBHAS5

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/154.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base for clam chowder. I made it the first time following the directions.  It needed a bit more though.  Ever since, I add 3 cans of chopped clams and 2 minced.  That kicks up the clam to enough.  I also added 4-5 strips of crumbled bacon and  cook the veggies in that along with clam juice from all the clams I opened up.  When you make this, make sure you cook the rue to get rid of that flour taste.  It only takes about 4-5 minutes, but so worth it.  I've used all half and half and sometimes half of half and half and the other half 2% milk.  Both are great to use.  The last few times I've made this, I've also added some tarragon near the end.  I love tarragon and I think it added just another  note to this already lovely soup.  My family loves it when I make this and there's never any leftovers.  Can't beat that.  Oh, and either serve it in some sourdough bread bowls or have some on the side.  So good!

userID:
17617990
Display Name:
Noejacks
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this clam chowder at least 5 times now and it is incredibly delicious and easy.  I love that it is a traditional fish-only chowder like my New England grandmother used to make. I do make three simple additions:

1.  I use four cans of clams instead of three.
2.  I add a couple teaspoons of Old Bay seasoning and dried Thyme when I add the salt and pepper.
3.  At the very end, I remove a one cup portion of chowder and blend it for about 30 seconds in the Vitamix. I then return it to the pot. This thins the chowder to a perfect texture without sacrificing flavor (like adding water does).
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Made changes to boost flavour. Crisped a few slices of diced bacon. Added butter after the vegetables. Minced 3 cloves of garlic. Deglazed with 2 capfuls of sherry. Then added flour. Threw in a couple dashes of cayenne and used no salt added chicken broth, clam juice from clams and a small bottle of clam juice. Simmered for about 1/2 hour, added the clams and heated through. Used 1 cup of whipping cream. Very good.

JessieB

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made it for dinner, and it turned out great! There are just a few notes I have.

First, if you're on a time budget and don't have all day to cook, you should put the veggies on high and let them boil in the broth. They'll simply stay as rocks if you keep them on medium. If you still want a little crunch, turning up the heat halfway through will do, but unless you like raw potatoes, you have to turn up the heat! On a positive note, I normally hate veggies (especially carrots), but the veggies, once softened, create a wonderful texture (and a little nutrition... you know, besides the crazy amount of butter).

Also, and this should have probably been something I should have known, but it's a good idea to give your clams a rinse before throwing them in. I found that some of the clams had a gritty bit to them, probably from dirt. It won't kill you (12 hours later, I'm just fine!), but it can hurt your teeth a little. Just a little rinse in water will fix the problem.

I made a few changes. First, I find vinegar far too sour for my taste, so I omitted it and added in some of my favorite spiced for taste and color: paprika, oregano, basil, garlic paste, onion powder, and parsley. I also used green onions instead of a regular onion. It's easier to cut, is very fragrant, and it doesn't make your eyes tear up. Though if you do this, put them in the broth when everything else is 10 minutes from being done, or they'll get soggy. I also added bacon (turkey bacon for us) like a lot of pe
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-09-04T20:28:52.617

text:
I did make a couple changes, but I loved it, so felt the need to give this recipe at least 4 stars. It was only me and my son eating, so I reduced the recipe to 3 servings and per suggestions, I first cooked 3 slices of bacon and used the grease to cook the onions . Then I used the grease and half the butter for the flour mixture. I didn't have extra clam juice (as some suggested using to cover veggies), so I used some chicken broth instead to add flavor. At the end I added the bacon bits. After all of that this dish was certainly NOT lacking flavor! So scrumptious. I look forward to making it for my husband when he returns from work. Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This is so good! I increase the veggies except onion to 3 cups each and add some frozen corn at the end. I melt the butter, cook the veggies, stir in the flour to cook 2 minutes while stirring, pour in clam juice from two 10 oz cans, add the milk (2%) mixed with a few schools of powdered milk. Our favorite seasonings are salt and black pepper to taste and about 1 t each parsley, thyme, and Old Bay seasoning. The clams and a few dashes if vinegar are stirred in before serving.

text:
This was awesome! Did make a couple of small changes...I chopped the onions (not finely) and instead of adding them to the broth in step 1, I sauted them in the butter in step 2 before adding in the flour. I also used 2 10 oz. cans of whole baby clams, instead of the chopped/minced clams. Made it really meaty. Don't skip the red wine vinegar...sheer genius. It really made it pop!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Stuff I added:

* I added 3 lg cloves of garlic   I used a yellow onion
* I used 3 yukon gold potatoes
* I skipped the carrots. They don't belong in clam chowder
* I used 1 Can whole clams and 1 Can chopped clams
* I added the juice of the Can of whole clams
* I used 3 celery stalks
* Added about a tablespoon of Thyme
* Added cayenne pepper
* Added a few splashes of Tobasco
* It was really thick so I gradually added about 2-3 Cups vegetable broth

Can't remember what else.  Just had fun with it.  A Bay Leaf would have been cool. I forgot to add it.  Also forgot to buy parsley for garnish, because I like making it pretty :)  Enjoy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is our absolute most favorite clam chowder recipe, with a couple modifications to suit our tastes! For the most part, I kept everything the same, except a couple things. I cooked the veggies in bacon fat (we keep leftover fat in a jar in the fridge, or you can cook fresh bacon), then instead of adding water to them, I use a bottle of clam juice. Also, I use a pint of heavy cream, plus a quart of half and half because we like ours thick. If it gets too thick I add milk. The only reason I gave it four stars instead of five is because of the changes I made. Fabulous, thank you!

text:
Very good, easy, quick clam chowder.  Few changes:  I had a couple strips of cooked bacon left over from breakfast.  Started by warming those in the pot before adding the onions, etc.  Just gave it that nice flavor.  I left the bacon in throughout the whole process.  Must thin (or thicken) to your own preference, the flavor does not suffer either way.  Although I am usually a vinegar fan, next time I will not add the vinegar.    I added a pinch of rosemary leaves.  Delish.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe for clam chowder. I followed other recommendations and browned a few strips of bacon in the skillet, drained the grease, added butter and EVOO and then cooked the veggies slightly before adding the clam juice and chicken stock instead of water. I don't use half and half, as it's just too rich and it kills me to use that much. I use regular 2% milk instead and it still comes out creamy and delish. You can substitute the proportion of milk/half and half as you desire, it's really a great base that you can tweak as you see fit. I've omitted the clams altogether and made it with lots of potatoes, cheddar, corn, and bacon or ham and just use it as a potato soup. It's very versatile. The vinegar really adds something special. Thanks so much for the great recipe, a definate keeper!

I tried it following the recipe.  I agree with others stating the roux makes it to thick. As I was tasting I could get no hints of clam but more of a almost potato soup thing. I added bacon as well and prepared that like the others said in the bacon fat. I only used clam juice, no water. I used chicken broth to thin it out, also I added a dash of Frank's hot sauce, white pepper, some fish sauce for more fish flavor, some  celery salt ,and thyme.   Next time I make it no roux maybe even regular milk and more potatoes.

text:
I've made this a few times. Exactly as written and with my own spin. It's a good base but it has a lot more potential. Def do the user recommend bacon thing and if you like actual bites of clam, use chopped clams vs minced. My one real criticism is that this is thick. Reallllllly thick. Personal pref but I like  soup to be a soup and not a stew. SO called it tasty clam gravy. I might use whole milk and see if I can't thin it out just a bit. If that doesn't work, I'm going to add more clam juice or more milk.

text:
Although the recipe is a great base there is one very vital ingredient missing... Salt pork! Always start with salt pork and sauté your onions in the drippings. Then follow through with the recipe.  The red wine vinegar is an added touch I've incorporated over the years. Does something for the end flavor. Oh... And remove the salt pork from the pot prior to proceeding.

My kids request this soup all of the time!  My husband also loves it.  I often make bacon and use the grease to sautee the onions and celery first.  Use some of the crumbled bacon on top for a nice presentation when serving. In addition to clams, I add multiple types of seafood:  crab, shrimp, scallops, and sometimes even calamari. I do add some cayenne pepper for a little spice to the soup, too!  Then serve this soup in bread bowls.  Yum!

text:
I will definitely make this again. I am putting here what I would normally put in my "personal notes" which is apparently no longer available. I used 4 small potatoes, 2 small carrots, and 3 celery stalks. Used 1/4 cup butter and 1/2 cup flour, and about 3 cups of milk. Then added water/clam juice from veggies and veggies, and simmered until desired thickness. Salt to taste, a lot of ground pepper, and a good bit of old bay. Used 2 10 oz cans of baby clams. Turned out great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVE, love love!!!  I have now made this many times over this summer and have tweaked it to be my own! First made following recipe. It is very good as is and an awesome base to make just the way you like it.  I prefer chowder to be a bit thinner, I didn't think the carrots added much to it and wanted more potatoes. I followed other suggestions to first brown and crumble about a 1/4 lb bacon to stir in at the end. I increased potatoes to 3 cups and substituted 1 cup corn for carrots. I decreased to 1/2 cup flour and use 2 cups half & half and 2 cup skim milk instead of quart half & half. I have used leftover fresh clams as well as the canned and both are good. I do prefer the chopped clams to the minced.
All of these adjustments took place over many excellent batches of a very good recipe to start with.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The recipe as is warrants 4 stars, but with the additions of bacon, bacon grease, and bottled clam juice (in place of water) as suggested by many reviewers, it's a 5 star recipe.  In the summer you might go with a slightly lighter chowder by subbing milk for some or all of the half-n-half.  In the winter we love it hearty, as is.  Another delicious variation is to dice 1 to 2 cups of white fish, like haddock, and use that in place of the canned clams.  In step 1, simmer veggies in clam juice until almost tender. Then add fish and continue simmering until it is flaky.  I still used bottle clam juice when using fish.

Great basic recipe. I have made this recipe a number of times and my family loves it. I do modify it to our liking by seasoning the veggies with seasonal all, onion and garlic powder, adding a little rosmary and tyme, and sometimes a splash of chicken broth with water replacing the yucky canned juice, and once even added scallops Yum!. My mods definitely change this recipe from being a classic clam chowder, but I'm sure glad I found it because it's still pretty good as is in my opinion.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If dairy doesn't agree with your stomach, you can omit the butter and half-half.   Here's how.... Soak 1 c. raw cashews for 2 hours or overnight.  Drain and blend cashews with 1-8 oz bottle clam juice and 2-3 t. cornstarch.  Blend till it is smooth and silky - no nutty lumps.  Add this to the veggie mixture at step #2 of the recipe and use more water to thin chowder to the right consistency.  Heat through 2-4 min, and move onto step #3.

This is a nice and easy clam chowder recipe. I also used a bottle of clam juice instead of water. The red wine vinegar is the key to this recipe, don't skip it.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the red wine vinegar is really optional. I tasted it before and after. I loved it before, not so much right after, but then once it sat for a little while, I couldn't really tell the difference, so either way it turns out fine (though, I only added 1 T and not the 2 called for).  I used clam juice in place of the water (3 bottles), and I poured the juices from 4 cans of minced and chopped clams into the pot as well.  Once the veggies were softened, I used a potato masher to mash it for a few seconds, to break up the potatoes a bit, because I like a thicker consistency. Also, I used half bacon grease and half butter for the roux, and  3 T. of cornstarch and 2 T of flour, rather than 3/4 cup of flour (I'm gluten sensitive, so I try to avoid wheat as much as I can).  I was worried it would all be too runny once I combined everything together, but it was the perfect consistency. I did let the clam juice and veggies reduce quite a bit, but there was still plenty of liquid in the pot before adding the half and half mixture.  Overall, I was very pleased.

country:

text:
Family said it was the best clam chowder they have ever had. I loved it too, but the calories!!! I cut my vegetables pretty small and they did cook fairly quickly, so I would recommend checking them frequently right from the start. (I would have preferred to have turned off the burner the moment the veggies became tender.) I cooked the half and half mixture until it was very thick prior to adding the vegetables, since I knew I would be watering it down with the clam juice/water mixture. I never did add all of the clam juice/water, just enough to get the consistency I was looking for in the clam chowder.  I did make one MISTAKE, I added Balsamic vinegar instead of the red wine vinegar. I thought maybe I had ruined the dish, but it was delicious with the Balsamic. Not sure if I would make again, even though it was very good because of the calories involved.

text:
I love clam chowder, but have never made it before. I must say I loved this!  I will make again soon.  I left out the carrots, simply because I didn't have them and think I will continue to leave them out as I don't see them adding anything to this.  I took others suggestions and fried a few strips of bacon first and added veggies to this, though next time I will brown up some of the onion first and try it that way before adding the liquid.  I added clam juice and some water to make the liquid and recommend this for a more clam flavor.  I will add more clams to my next batch for more flavor, but bought all the store had at the time and didn't want to run out to another store.  I cooked my cream mixture till it was nice and thick and it ended up being perfect when added to liquid.  I liked the nice creamy, rich texture of the soup.  Although this is not the healthy version of the soup, it is a great treat.

text:
I made a few changes to this recipe which made it a 5 star in my house ! I used freshly shucked little neck clams and oysters which made all the difference in flavor. I also used 2 cups chicken broth and 2 cups half and half. I did not have any red wine vinegar so I used cider vinegar and I also added 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper for some kick. Absolutely delicious!!

text:
Delicious!  My kids and husband said better than some coastal restaurants in San Francisco and Monterey!   I happened to have some bacon oil left from breakfast this morning so used that to sauté the vegetables.  I added 2 cloves garlic. I used the half and half and added fresh parsley and garlic salt.  I didn't have red wine vinegar so I used 1T rice vinegar + 1T red wine cooking sherry.  Came out very creamy and rich!  A small bowl was satisfying.  I will definitely make this again.

text:
Clam chowder is not my thing but it is my husbands and he said this is the best he has ever had or it would be if I cooked the veggies down a bit.  I did the bacon grease as others suggested.  I used 2 cans of minced clams and 2 cans of chopped clams.  I used 8 oz of clam juice instead of water and I cut the carrots down to 1/2 a cup of shredded.  I like clam chowder, I've certainly had it before however it is not something I would order in a restaurant but this was good.  Next time I will saute the onion and celery and carrots in the bacon grease for a little bit before covering them with the clam juice per my husbands request and he said although it isn't typical some corn might be good in here.... Also one more can of chopped clams.....I think I will do that.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe, and adding the fat from some strips of bacon to replace part of the butter (I use three bacon strips' fat to replace 1/4 c), it tastes fantastic! However, I do not use the actual bacon itself as I have tried crumbling and using one, two and three strips at different times, and the whole family prefers the slight smoky flavour to a full-on bacon-y one.

I make this once a week and EVERYONE (hubby, son, MIL, FIL...moi) all looks forward to it!

Add Pillsbury's Corn Biscuits (come in cans of 8) and you have a cracker meal!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a classic recipe that went over extremely well.  Loved the addition of carrots.  I also cooked down 5 pieces of bacon and used the grease with the clam juice to cook the vegetables down.  In addition I included about a cup of red wine to the cooking vegetables.  I added the crumbled bacon in the end with cooked steamers (cleaned), thawed clams, and already cooked halibut (other white fish would be fine as well).  Rave reviews from those that grew up on clam chowder in Maine on the coast there entire life (best I have ever had).  I did utilize light cream instead of half and half and also had to add more water as it was too thick.  Perhaps cut down on the amount of flour, 3/4 cup is a bit much.  Enjoy!

text:
The vegetable portion with the clam juice was fine, however the cream mixture was very very thick, after combining the 2 parts, the ladle actually will rest on the top of the soup without sinking.I think it probably would work with half of the flour called for.  I added 2 cups of chicken to thin a little.  Also  I added the vinegar as many reviewers thought it added,but be prepared you will have a vinegar taste which is fantastic with bean soup, but not what I expect with a chowde
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-12-24T18:26:24.61
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! It is my go to "clam" (or corn/ no clam, since I'm a vegetarian) chowder. I make it a few times per year and have since I found it two years ago. For the vegans/ vegetarians out there, simply replace the clam juice w 1+ cup of vegetable broth and if you are making corn chowder, put the excess liquid you have drained from the corn in to start. I have made this soup so many times and never experienced the lack of flavor some of the other reviews comment on. It may be because I start w vegetable broth and not the clam juice? I do tend to adjust seasonings as I taste to ensure it is flavorful enough (I do this w all recipes, though). Enjoy!

text:
Awesome but I used the clam juice instead of water to soften veggies, also adding 1 tsp of oregano and 1/2 tsp of thyme while they cooked I also added corn instead of carrots which I didn't have on hand. I drained veggies set aside and used juice to make a roux. using cornstarch instead of flour. using both 1/2 & 1/2 cream and milk to make to your own consistency add veggies warm gently not to boil add clams heat and serve. cant wait to make it again

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This gets five stars with my modification. Instead of adding water to cover the vegetables, I added a bottle of clam juice. After putting it together and adding the clams, I added about one cup of bacon crumbles (store bought.) It had thickened so much from everything that I added another half bottle of clam juice. I also used 1 tsp of course kosher salt instead of 1 1/2 tsp regular salt. I've tried the other suggestion of cooking it in bacon grease but I think this method tastes way better and has more bacon flavor, believe it or not. It is really yummy in a bread bowl or served with Garlic Texas toast.

Nice recipe...per other reviewers, needs all FIVE cans of clams....get 2 minced, and 3 chopped cans clams.  Buy small clam juice to use instead of water.  Used 1/2 and 1/2 and also small amt heavy cream.  Thickened with cornstarch (1/3 cup) and water instead of flour.  Perfect consistency.  Hubby had a huge bowl to eat and we had 2 large Tupperware containers of leftovers.  Only takes about 30 mins to make, great for weeknight dinner.

text:
Very good and easy to make clam chowder! For me it needed just 2 adjustments. The first being more clams. I used the recipe calc. to cut down to four servings , which called for 1 1/2 cans of clams. I put in 2 cans and was still a bit short. Next time I will use 3 cans to make 4 servings. The other adjustment was to add Old Bay seasoning with the salt and pepper to add a bit more seafood taste. I then baked an olive cheese spread on the bread and it was a meal fit for a King!

text:
So delicious but 4 stars since I had to make changes. Here is what I changed:

-cooked 6 strips of bacon in skillet, then used the grease when cooking the veggies, added bacon at end of cokking
-used 4 cans of clams instead of 3. This was enough clam juice to cover the veggies so I didn't use any water
-scaled back the celery and increased the carrots (personal preference) as well as used 3 cups of sweet potatoes instead of regular potatoes.

Overall, tasted great. Since I didn't use any water, I will scale back the salt next time as well as try healthier options to see if I can cut down some of the fat.

text:
Made this yesterday, and have to agree that it is really quite delicious and easy to make.  I found that the drained clam juice was plenty of liquid to cook the veggies in.  And I used half 1% milk with the half-and-half to cut down on the richness (and fat).  It was still plenty thick for my husband, who prefers thicker cream soups.  I would like to try it with cooked, crumbled bacon another time, for extra flavor.  I liked the feature that changed the recipe for a different number of servings--made it for 4 servings instead of 8, since it was just for the two of us.

text:
This is the first recipe I've ever rated - I admit I used some of the recommendations of others, and I have to say it was amazing.  I made the clam chowder this past weekend for a community clambake - so I made enough for 30 people.  It was so easy to increase the recipe size, and I got more compliments than I ever imagined.  I was told it was the best clam chowder ever, and at the very least it was among the very best.  Thanks for sharing this recipe, and thanks for all the great suggestions for improving it! The most important improvements included using the bacon grease, cooking the flour long enough not to leave a pasty taste, using a little less vinegar (I used white balsamic rather than red wine), and adding the old bay.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick and easy, and a real crowd-pleaser. I usually add one or more of the following items to the basic recipe:
1. a dash of cayenne;
2. kernels from an ear of fresh corn -- I add this towards the end, because they don't need to cook much;
3. a diced red bell pepper, which I roast in a dry frypan until it scorches a little (the pepper, not the frypan);
4. some fresh herbs -- a bit of minced lemon sage is nice.
5. Last but not least -- whole milk instead of cream. Didn't miss the cream one bit.

text:
This is my first time making this and i just have to write how awesome clam chowder really is! It's creamy and filling. Tweaked the recipe a little after reading the reviews too. Only used one large pot (hate doing dishes), browned some bacon, removed them and let them drain. Then, I added the vegetables, water and clam juice to the bacon fat til tender. Added butter to pot. In medium bowl, measured out flour and mixed some half and half til smooth then added to pot. Poured rest of cream and heated through added clams. Forgot to add vinegar though. Soup was still great though! Thanks for the recipe.

This was my first time making clam chowder and WOW - what a crowd pleaser.  My 10 & 8 year olds LOVED this recipe.   Made  a few modifications - added the salt, pepper, & a bit of thyme into the veggies while cooking.  Like other reviewers I added the veges to the bacon fat. Let the veges saute a bit in the pot before adding the clam juice.  Also, didn't add any water - instead used clam juice to cover veges..  Used condensed milk & skim milk in lieu of half & half.  Went well with "from scratch" biscuits (also from allrecipes).  Will ABSOLUTELY be making this again....and again....and again....

I don't generally like clam chowder but my family love it. I actually liked this soup! The red wine vinegar made the soup! I did the bacon thing suggested by others, which I wouldn't skip. Due to picky eaters, I didn't add celery or carrots, but I did sprinkle in some celery seed. It was a little thicker than we liked so I think I'll cut back on the flour next time. Keeper.

text:
Great chowder recipe! I followed others' advice and cooked 4 pieces of bacon first. I wiped out almost all of the grease, then cooked the veggies in the same pan with clam juice and water. I was trying to make it lower fat, so I used about 1/8 cup margarine instead of the butter. I mixed the flour with fat free 1/2 and 1/2 before pouring into butter so it wouldn't clump. I only had about 3 cups 1/2 and 1/2 so added an additional cup of fat free milk. Did not miss the fat at all. My two kids (9 and 6) both loved it, too.

text:
Excellent!  I added more chopped clams, sauteed the onions in bacon fat, used fat-free half & half, no celery & carrots, less butter and thickened it with a little potato flakes.  Tried it without the vinegar and it was good.  After adding the vinegar it was fantastic.  Don't skip the red wine vinegar.  I myself didn't eat it with the bacon crumbles as some suggested because I loved it the way it was.  However the family had the bacon crumbles.  Everyone loved it.  I will be making this often this winter.  EDIT:  DON'T SKIP THE VINEGAR!  I now use vinegar on even the canned Campbells & Progresso stuff just so I can get close to the taste of this awesome chowder.  Dang this cook has it together!  My taste buds thank you!

text:
I loved this chowder! This is the first time I ever made it and I could not believe how easy it was. This is excellent and easily adaptable to suit your own personal tastes. You can add bacon as other reviewers described, some hot peppers finely chopped to spice it up, or even drained diced tomatoes.  I served mine with some traditional Native American fry bread and it was a hit. The soup is very filling but I would recommend doubling the recipe for a larger family because it will go fast. Thanks for the recipe! I am sure that it will become a favorite in our home!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!  I also cooked about 4 strips of bacon (which i chopped and added later) then cooked the vegetables in the grease for a few minutes before adding the clam juice (all clam juice, no water).  I used heavy cream instead of the 1/2 & 1/2, but ended up having to add about a cup or two of 1%milk because it looked too thick.  I think I would have been fine either way because you get a nice texture once you add all the juice and veges. I went with 2 cans of whole baby clams and 1 can chopped. Next time i'll probably throw in a can of minced too and maybe even another can of the whole ones.  I added a tiny bit of nutmeg and cumin at the end for complexity.    Definitely restaurant quality..and easy too!

First time I've made homemade Clam Chowder other than the cheating method ala cream of celery soup..which was good, but not the real thing.  I must say this recipe proved to be a real winner...I did do the bacon addition as recommended by some other reviewers.  It was fabulous!  It was our Christmas Eve dinner!!  I had one person say, it was "the best clam chowder I have ever had".  Wow!  Well, meantime, I have enjoyed it for the last couple days, of course, thinning out, once with 1/2 AND 1/2 AND today with fat free milk...It only got better ( of course, little tobasco sauce just added another dimension).   Thanks, PIONEERGIRL for a great recipe.  I look forward to when I can serve it to guests the next time..a true keeper.

This is an excellent recipe! I made a few changes though. I added a bit of thyme time at the end and used 3 table spoons of red wine vineager-it tasted deliciousl. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Originally I gave this recipe 4 stars. The first time I made it I used fat free half-and-half, and I think that is what made it sweeter than I would prefer. After making it again, with some changes, I give this 5 stars. As far as changes, I use 5 cans CHOPPED clams, 3 cups cubed potatoes, and light cream instead of half-and-half. Also, instead of using water to completely cover the vegetables, I used clam juice. It came out fantastic! Very thick and creamy (which is fine with me). It it is too thick, you can always substitute some milk for maybe half the cream to thin in out a bit. I might try that sometime. I also plan to up the recipe and try 7 cans of chopped clams. Can't have too many clams. Overall, great recipe.

I was a little worried after reading some of the negative comments, but this was a great recipe! I think it would be a 5 star with the following changes: I also cooked the vegetables in the bacon grease, I would leave out the carrots because it is a little odd in a chowder, and I would definitely add a 4th can of clams and juice to give it that extra taste. I will definitely be making this again! Very easy and delicious. Thanks!

text:
I know I know people hate it when you alter the recipe and then you post a review on it, but I wanted to add my little tweak to it and post it so that others might like it that way.. Instead of 3 cans of clams I only did 2, and then I also added quarter pound of shrimp meat (those little cooked shrimps) and a quarter pound of scallops (cut them small, and pan fried them with some butter and garlic)..and instead of carrots...that i forgot to buy..i just put in mushrooms, lol that was really really good! I highly recommend adding in some more seafood to make it a seafood chowder..so hearty and good! Oh! Definitely use fresh clams if you can, that's the only thing that I would do differently.

text:
Made this chowder last night because we needed something to do with a recently caught geoduck. Got two cans of clams as well for their juice and to make the chowder extra clammy. Substituted one cup milk for part of the half and half and also mashed one and a half boiled potatoes into the broth to make it thicker. Also added some fresh dill. The red wine vinegar is a GREAT touch. Really happy to have leftovers for lunch today.

text:
This was my first attempt at Clam Chowder.  It was very good.  I used the suggestion of another and added 6 strips of cooked crumbled bacon.  I also sauteed the veggies in some of the bacon grease and then added the clam juice till the veggies were tender.  I also added cut up cooked shrimp and some flaked crab meat.  I did not add the red wine vinegar.  It was awesome and my boyfriend loved it and I've made it now several times.  Thanks -Great recipe!

Both the original and custom recipes are awesome and I highly recommend making this!

text:
Really a great chowder... I would give it 5 but we feel it needs just a little something more so I'm going to give it 4 stars... but still a great chowder!  I followed the suggestion of using the bacon grease to sautee the onions, celery, carrots & potatoes.  I also used whole milk vs. half and half but I do that with every chowder recipe.  We had a blizzard the day I made this and didn't realize I was out of red wine vinegar and no stores were open, so we took a little out and stirred in balsamic... we did the same for rice vinegar and sherry... finally we found that Worchestershire sauce was really good... I added maybe a half tablespoon as it is a very strong flavor.  

Definately a keeper!  I'm just going to see if I can figure out what is missing... it's very slight but we feel it just needs a little something... just not sure what it is yet!  This is certainly worth a try!  :-)

text:
Very yummy and easy clam chowder recipe. The red wine vinegar really makes this dish. I also added bacon and used the dripping to sautee the onion and celery before adding the potatoes and clam juice. I used 4 cans of clams (2 chopped, 2 minced), so I had enough juice to cover the veggies. I couldn't get myself to use all that butter so I substituted most of it with olive oil. I also used 2 cups 1/2 and 1/2 and 2 cups 1% milk. The richness is definitely still there! Great recipe for a cold and windy day.

text:
I made this as an appetizer for a small dinner party; everyone loved it.  I omitted the celery, carrots and clams completely.  As usual, I sauteed the onions and potatoes in the bacon grease, but I added garlic.  After adding the water/vegetable mix to the butter/flour/half and half mix, you might find that the "soup" is too thick.  Thin it down with milk.  I used a salt mix called "vegeta" which worked well.  The red wine vinegar should be at least 2 tablespoons, and as much as 3.  It really makes a difference.

Like many others, I fried up some turkey bacon and then stir-fried the vegetables in the bacon grease.  I omitted the carrots (in clam chowder? really?), and added a small bag of frozen corn instead, which added a great splash of color. The soup was AMAZING, and tasted like a combination of corn chowder & clam chowder.  Easy and tasty, but I'll probably only make it once a year, because of the fat content.

text:
Very Yummy!  I gave 4 starts because I changed a couple of things.  As another reviewer suggested, I fried up 5 strips of bacon in the pan first, removed (and saved to crumble in at the end) and then sauteed the veggies in that, then added the clam juice.  Also, I did 2 cups half and half and the other 2 cups 2% milk and it was plenty thick and rich enough.  I actually added a bit of water at the end because it was a bit too thick.

text:
Great clam chowder recipe!!!  I tripled the recipe to make for a large group and I also wanted plenty leftover for the next day and it still turned out fantastic.  My only changes to the recipe were that I DOUBLED the amount of minced clams called for.  I had so much of the other ingredients the minced clams seemed out of proportion.  I also added extra canned clam juice to cover the vegetables with because I had so much potatoes, carrots, onion and celery I needed more clam juice than that which came with the clams to cover the veggies.  I could have used water, but I think the clam juice added much more flavor as others have suggested.  Some minor doctoring aside with certain spices I like in almost all my soups and this was ready to rock.  By far the best homemade clam chowder I have ever tasted and my company agreed very enthusiastically.  Thanks for the recipe Pioneergirl…it’s a winner!

text:
Wow - this is GREAT with crusty bread for dipping.  I'm not sure it's cheaper than buying a couple of cans of good quality clam chowder, but it sure is healthier.  I used fat-free half and half which was a mistake - the soup came out tasting very sweet.  I had to use a lot of salt and vinegar (probably 4-5x the written amount) to clear the sweet taste.  Next time I'll use regular half-and-half.  I'll probably use more clams, too, just because we love them.  Thanks!

text:
Was searching for a great Clam Chowder.  This was excellent.  I made a few modifications following other review comments.  I did not add any water.  I used the clam juice from the canned clams and added clam juice from a bottle for the rest.  I did not add carrots (my son said clam cowder does not have carrots).  The Vinagar is a must.  Very nice rich consistency.  Served for Friday dinner with crusty beard and fresh green salad.

text:
Received three "This is the best clam chowder I've ever had" comments, and I'll add my own. Absolutely delicious! I used one pint half & half and one pint 2% - VERY creamy - and was only brave enough to add 1 T balsamic vinegar (no red wine vinegar on hand). Next time I'll try the 2 T because it added a real depth to the soup. Omitted carrots (yuck!) and added an extra can of chopped clams (3 minced, 1 chopped for chunkiness). Also used 1/2 jar of clam juice to cook veggies instead of water. Slurp!

text:
Seems superfluous to add my review when there's already 275 reviews, but I will anyway--this is some awesome chowder! My husband said it was the best he'd ever had, and I think it's definitely up there among the best. I put in a pint of half-and-half and a pint of 1% milk, rather than the full quart of half-and-half. I also added a couple of leftover sea bass filets from a previous meal, cut into small chunks. I'd cooked them blackened-style, so they added a little extra to the overall flavor. I also put in a tsp. of Old Bay with the veggies while they cooked in the clam juice. This is a great soup to make straight or play with.

text:
I'd really give it a 4 1/2. This is really a very tasty chowder! My husband and I loved this recipe! Made it as is but added a handful of dried parsley for color, skipped the carrots & red wine vinegar (didn't have either) and 2 cooked and chopped slices of turkey bacon. It's simple and so are the flavors, in a good way though! It would be a 5 but it wasn't quite clam-y enough to suit our taste. It has a very mild clam flavor. If you like a stronger clam flavor to come through I would suggest using double the amount of clams and do not be afraid to use the liquid from 6 cans of clams - this makes a very thick chowder. We will absolutely be making it again! Outstanding recipe, Sharon. Thanks!

text:
Wow, this recipe is fantastic.  After many attempts at trying to make a good clam chowder, having only failing miserably, this recipe came through, and even better than I expected.  I did change a few things though.  I first fried up four slices of bacon and sauteed the onions and celery in the bacon grease before adding the clam juice,  added only 1/2 cup of flour instead of the 3/4 cup that the recipe calls for, used only a 1/4 cup of celery instead of 1 cup, and omitted the carrots.  This came out great!  The entire family loved it at the pot was gone in just a few minutes.  Absolutely delicious.  I will definitely make it again.

text:
This wasn't bad for my first try at clam chowder. I followed recipe exactly - no substitutions. Like some others I found it to be on the liquidy side - I'm used to the thicker stuff at restaurants. But unlike some others that said all they could taste was flour - I didn't. Actually, I couldn't taste hardly anything at all except the celery! I agree that it needs something - perhaps more clams or clam juice - not sure since I've never made it before. Oh - and the red wine vinegar wasn't good - not inedible but I wouldn't do it again! I guess I'll keep looking for the perfect clam chowder.

userID:
990527
Display Name:
Pamela28
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
36
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe four stars but I didn't make it quite this way.  We are a cajun/south Texan family so crawfish was a must.  First I omitted the carrots, then I cooked the celery, onions, & potatos in chicken broth (to cover) until the broth was mostly gone.  I set that aside and sauted 1-2 lbs of crawfish tail meat in a little butter until done and set that aside.  Then I followed the butter, flour, half & half directions except I used 2 c. half & half and 2 c. 2% milk.  (It still comes out so thick I end up using more milk to thin it out) Finally I dump the meat and veggies in and let the whole thing heat through adding some CajunLand seasoning to the whole thing.  Served with hot french bread....yum!!  It is a little rich so it maybe best served as an appetizer or leave the potatos out and serve over fish or maybe even leave thick and served with toasted baguettes as a dip.

4

text:
We live near a coastal area and have access to some wonderful seafood restaurants where we have sampled many different clam chowders.  This recipe rivals some of the best we have had!  
I divided the quart of half and half using 1/2 whole milk and 1/2 of the half and half and it was still rich without being heavy or "floury." (Which can be a problem with some clam chowders.)
My 12-year-old son helped me with the preparation and we had fun making this soup together.  
It was even better for lunch the next day!
